The members of that conference recognised that protection must come first; that the work must be here before we can have good wages, and that when we have secured the work for the men, this Parliament-o r as the law now stands, the State Parliamentmust insist on reasonable conditions of labour being observed. I would direct attention to a very interesting return published in the Age on 24th ult., showing that the importation of goods, the manufacture of which offers scope for local employment at fair wages, is increasing at an alarming rate. I find, for instance, that the imports of machines and machinery last year were of the value of ^851,797, whilst those imported during the first seven months of this year were of the value of ^1,067,841. These figures show very clearly that there is every reason for passing a Tariff which will give our manufacturers a home market.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Most of the imported machinery is patented.

Speaker: Mr MAUGER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is not so.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That which is not patented here, could be manufactured in Australia.

Speaker: Mr MAUGER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is so. lieve that all machinery except that which is protected by patents should and could be manufactured in Australia, and no duty will be effective or satisfactory to me unless it secures the local market to the local manufacturer.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Cowper) [4.25] - The honourable member for Melbourne Ports has directed attention" to a phase of this question that has not been considered as fully as it might have been. After referring to the cost of distribution, he urged that the profits made by the local manufacturers are not very large, and that the farmers could not do better than buy agricultural implements and machinery made in Australia. The honourable member also contended that every machine imported into Australia displaces an Australian machine, and an Australian workman. That assertion could be made of almost any imported article. It is worthv of note that the honourable member refrained from making any allusion to the way in which the farmers have been blackmailed by manufacturers, who have been demanding very high prices for their goods. I have no sympathy with the Massey-Harris Company, or the International Harvester Company. I certainly have none for the local manufacturers who combined with the foreign firms to fleece the farmers.

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The local manufacturers lowered the price after they left the combine.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: And they could further reduce the price of their machines by ,Â£10 and yet secure a good profit. The Tariff Commission has revealed the fact that the farmers are simply being black-mailed by have. the local manufacturers of harvesters. As the result of the disclosures made by Butter Commission, the dairymen have established co-operative societies to with their produce, and I think that the time is not far distant when those engaged in primary industries will co-operate to wipe out, not only the local, but the foreign manufacturers who have been fleecing them. I . for one, would give them every assistance in taking steps in that direction. It is outrageous that a profit of ^40 should be secured on one of these machines. The Massey-Harris Company have conclusively proved what is the cost of their harvesters.. With all due deference to the Minister of Trade and Customs, I wish to say that I am prepared to accept the opinion exI bepressed by his predecessor in office-the honourable member for Gippsland-that the invoices in respect of the Massey-Harris machines imported into Australia are correct. When holding office as Minister of Trade and Customs, the honourable member for Gippsland was disposed to believe that these machines were being invoiced at a price below their real value; but when he went to the fountain head he secured information that satisfied him that the invoices were correct. The report of the Tariff Commission shows that this industry, instead of languishing, is in a verysatisfactory condition. Indeed, I know of no more profitable industry in Australia. Instead of having under consideration a motion to increase the duty on harvesters, we should be taking steps to prevent our farmers being treated in such a scandalous way as they have been. The present state of affairs should not be allowed to continue. The farmers, by co-operation, could, like their fellow workers on the Continent of Europe, secure their machines at cost price. It is monstrous that Â£,\o should be paid by way of commission on the sale of the harvester. I cannot agree with the proposal of the honourable member for Parramatta that an ad valorem dutyshould be imposed. As a rule, an ad valorem duty operates fairly, but it would not be safe to place the working of such a duty in the hands of a Minister who, for Customs purposes, has arbitrarily raised the valuation of these machines from ^38 to Â£ 6 5 each. Under the Customs Act, the importers of harvesters have no right of appeal'-the y have no means of redress.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I think that they will

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not think that the Custhe toms Act provides' any means of redress. It must be given as a concession. It has deal been said that the Canadians and Americans have pirated the Australian machines; but a plough which came from America was very quickly copied in Australia.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Does the honourable member say that there is in Australia good plough made on an American model

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Yes ; the "Bluebird" such a plough. If the Australian model has been copied, it is the greatest ment that could be paid to its inventor.

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If the honourable member were the inventor he would not be pleased about it.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I might not like it. The stripper-harvester, however, is not the vention of the brains of any one man. According to the Tariff Commission, harvesting implement was in use in ancient Gaul. This machine is the result of many brains, not all of them possessed by Ausinto tralians, though I understand that the latest improvements are Australian, and give every credit to those who have perof fected it.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The modern harvester is entirely the product of Australian brains and enterprise.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Australia n farmers not be fleeced when they want to purchase it. The honourable member for Moira presents a farming constituency, and tried to prove that the local manufacturers not receive too much for their implements. He denounced in unmeasured terms the importation of harvesters from Canada and America, but he did not mention . fact that Australian harvesters are being imported into Canada, eleven having been sent there last year.

Speaker: Mr MAUGER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: As patterns, I suppose.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Stripper-harvester s hitherto not been much used in Canada, but, - no doubt, the farmers there are ginning to try the Victorian implement, if rates of duty are increased. and I hope that there will be a good market for it in the Dominion.

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: How can there he good market for it there with a 45 per cent, duty against it?

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Canadian rate, according to the Commission, works out at about I 3 i per cent. Honourable members wish to impose a fixed rate of Â£ 1 6 per machine, although it has been shown that the ject of wages? locally made implement has an advantage of some Â£ 1 8 over the imported implement. The honourable memis ber for Moira tried to show that' the higher the duty the less the consumer - to pay; but the Victorian stock tax did not discussion. work out in that way. Victorians could not buy cattle more cheaply because of the tax. The honourable member for a Gippsland, although he has declared that ? he will support a duty of; 25 per cent^ is says that had he been a member of the Commission, he would not have recomcomplimended so high a rate. He considers that the locally made implement has an advantage of Â£ 2 0 . The evidence before us shows that the Australian production of harvesters is increasing every year. Something like 4,000 machines are now being inmade in Victoria, and a fixed rate of ,Â£16 on each imported machine would make a a difference of something like ^64,000, which is too much to take out of the pockets of the primary producers to put the pockets of the manufacturers. The farmers must take this matter into their I own hands, and, by co-operation, get rid both the foreign and the local manufacturers who are living on the game. I am proud of our Australian workmen, who can turn out articles equal to any imported; the advantages derived from High duties should go, not to them, but to their employers. I do not blame Mr MCKay for retrying to get as much as he can from a Minister who listens to his comdo plaints with a sympathetic ear. His business, however, is not in a languishing condition. In 1897 he manufactured 75 machines, on which it is estimated that the he made a net profit of ,Â£20 each, or now .Â£1,500 altogether. In 1898, his output was 150 machines , and his profit .Â£3,000; 1 in 1899, his output was 301 machines, and his profit ,Â£6,000; while in 1.904, his profit have was .Â£30,000; and in 1905, ^38,600. It is trying to throw dust in the eyes of the befarmers to say that prices will be reduced They should bear in mind this profit of .Â£38,600 made by one firm, and, by proper co-operaa tion, supply themselves with agricultural machinery. I shall oppose the Government proposal.

Speaker: Mr STORRER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I ask, as a point of order, whether honourable members must not confine their remarks to the amendment proposed last night, which deals with the sub

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The whole question so involved that it is impossible to confine honourable members to the amendment, and I has have, therefore, allowed the usual general  Government propose to levy a fixed duty on imported harvesters of \jÂ£i6 per machine. According to the report of the Tariff Commission, the natural protection given to local manufacturers against the competition of the Massey-Harris machines is ^14 16s. 6d., and against the competition of the International harvesters .Â£12 3s. 6d., the difference being accounted for, I believe, chiefly by a difference in railway charges. If to this natural advantage the proposed duty is added, it will be seen that the local manufacturers are as'king for an advantage of ^30 16s. 6d. in connection with the Massey-Harris machine, and of ,Â£28 3s. 6d. in connection with the International harvesters. We have the testimony of the chief of the Customs Office in Canada that the cost of the Canadian machines is ^38 each. Therefore, what is desired by the local manufacturers is a protection of more than 75 per cent - a prohibitive rate such as must delight the honourable member for Melbourne Ports. It might be well contended that the existing duty is sufficientlyhigh, seeing that none of the local manufacturers have shown that they are suffering from the foreign competition. Mr MCKay, who is the prime mover in the agitation for prohibitive duties, has had to admit that last year his output was 1,930 machines, and the Tariff Commission estimates that his net profits on each machine, on last years selling price, which was ;Â£8i, amounted to ;Â£i8 2s. 7d. That being so, why should we impose the monstrous duty now asked for. On thesefigureshis profits amounted last year to over .Â£34,700. which is more than 200 average farmers make in any one year. Those figures show that the industry is fairly protected. But still the manufacturers are not satisfied. It is evidently desired to shut out the imported article altogether, and leave the farmers to the tender mercies of the local firms. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports would have us believe that the consumers would be perfectly safe under these conditions. We have, however, had evidence that, some time ago, the manufacturers deliberately entered into a conspiracy to rob the farmers. - stated in trie report furnished by the protectionist members of the Tariff Commission that the local manufacturers increased the price of stripper harvesters from XÂ° 3 to Â£ 8 1 . We are now asked to hand over the farmers body and soul to those who have had no mercy upon them in the past, and who would have as little consideration in the future if their operations were not to some extent checked by outside competition. It has been urged that a high duty should be imposed to protect local manufacturers, because higher wages prevail in Australia than in the United States or Canada. As a matter of fact, however, the Commission show that the rates* of wages paid in Canada are practically the same as those ruling in the works of the Sunshine Harvester Company.

Speaker: Mr MAUGER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Accordin g to the statements made by some honourable members, the Sunshine Harvester Company pay lower wages than any other firm.  regard to the statements made by other honourable members, but I am relying upon the evidence taken by the Tariff Commission. I intend to quote the rates of wages paid, and to make an allowance for the extra hours worked in Canada - According to the evidence given before the Commission, fitters in Canada are paid Â£ 2 13s. per week, whilst in the Sunshine Harvester works they are paid Â£ 2 ns. 6d. per week. Joiners in Canada are paid - Q2 15s. 5d., and in Australia Â£ 2 ns. 3d. Painters in Canada are paid Â£ 2 16s. 8d. per week, and in Australia 15s. 6d. Blacksmiths, in Canada are paid f.2 16s. 6d. per week, and in Australia Â£ 2 9s. 6d. per week! Right through, the piece, the rates paid in Canada are higher than those received by the workmen of the Sunshine Harvester Company. I desire to be perfectly fair, and I intend to make a deduction from the Canadian wages, owing to the fact that the operatives work for sixty hours per week, as contrasted with the forty-eight hours worked in Australia. According to the experts who were examined by the Commission, 30 per cent, of the cost of producing the machines is represented by labour. It is admitted that in Canada the cost of producing the machines is .Â£38, but a South Australian manufacturer mentioned a much smaller sum as representing the cost. On the assumption that the machine costs .Â£38 to produce, the wages represent I^Â£i2 8s. If we make allowance for the extra hours It is worked by the Canadian mechanics, the local manufacturers are at a disadvantage, as compared with those in Canada, of ^Â£2 9s. 4d. per machine, in respect to wages. And yet, in order to compensate the Australian manufacturer for this small loss, we are being asked to impose a duty equivalent' t 0 Â£ 3 Â° per machine. It seems to me that the request that is now being made upon us is a most brazen one. Now I desire to say a word or two with regard to the action of .the Minister of Trade and Customs in increasing the valuation of imported harvesters to , Â£ 6 5. It is a dangerous thing for a Minister to increase a duty at any time. He has very large powers, and they should be used with extreme care. Commission have made a full inquiry into the valuation of imported harvesters, and the protectionist members-no t the free trade members-of that body have come to the conclusion that there is not a tittle of evidence to justify the increased valuation. Under these circumstances, it seems to me that the only manlv course open to the Minister is to acknowledge that he has made a mistake, and to refund the duty collected over and above that which would have been levied upon the lower valuation.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Minister made no such mistake. twopence for such protectionists as could bring in a report of that kind. not the evidence they should have had before them.  when the Minister will be very glad of the support of the members of the Commission who came to the conclusion to which I have referred. His statement is a mere subterfuge. He should either prove that the evidence given before the Tariff Commission is wrong, or produce the testimony which he states that the members of the Commission have not seen, and which would prove that he was justified in increasing the valuation to ^ 6 5 . He should do this, or admit that he has made a mistake.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I have made no mistake, and the courts will prove it, yet.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Is that why the Minister tiied to prevent the courts from proving it?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not like tectionists of the milk and water order. Witnesses were frightened to go before the Commission and give evidence, owing to the action of some members of the Commission.. I could not induce one witness to go, because he would not submit to be bullied by the Commission.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Was the Minister trying to find witnesses?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No , I was not.  mean to say that any witness who was willing to give evidence would not have received the protection of the Chairman, and fair play at the hands of the other members of the Commission.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Some witnesses did not receive fair play. They were bullied by a member of the Commission from Tasmania.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Order ! I must ask the Minister to cease these continuous interjections. The Sir WILLIAM LYNE - Let honourable members cease attacking me.

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Minister made an unnecessary reflection upon a public man. .  should be exercised by any Minister in raising the valuations of imports in such a manner as to practically increase the duty to which they are subject. I am prepared to believe that the Minister did what he thought was right, but now that the Commission, after due deliberation, have stated that there was not a scintilla of evidence has to justify the fixing of the valuation of I would not give stripper-harvesters at Â£ 6 5 , the Minister should justify his position, or withdraw They had the increased valuation. - Sir WILLIAM LYNE - I shall withdiaw the duty on salt if the honourable member likes.  suppose that such statements hurt me? If so, he is mistaken. There is the more necessity for the Minister to justify his position, because his predecessor was so satisfied with the previous valuation that he declined to increase it.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: But'he did increase it from Â£26 to Â£ $ .  which satisfied him that Â£ 5 8 was a fair valuation.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Bu the did not obtain the evidence.  upon the evidence of a man who was inproterested in the trade, and that is a verydangerous thing to do in any case. The Minister acted upon the evidence of a man who, in the face of a sworn declaration upon the other side, said that to the best of his belief the invoices were wrong. The Commission have succeeded in obtaining very complete evidence as to the cost of stripper-harvesters, and, if I were the Minister, I would not sit in my chair an hour before I would justify myself or acknowledge that I had been misled by the information supplied to me, and take the manly course of withdrawing the increased valuation.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not think that the honourable member can accuse me of having failed to take a manly course.  it was a dangerous thing for the Minister to increase the valuation. Such a course should be adopted only under extreme pressure, and after the Minister had satisfied himself that there was the fullest warrant for such a step. The conditions under which the local industry was being carried on were not such as to call for any special action. The local manufacturers were not being subjected to any very severe hardships. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports knows very well what was the reason for the agitation. The Minister cannot ignore the fact that eight gentlemen who must be credited with being as much concerned for the welfare of the manufacturing industries as he is himself, have come to the. conclusion that there is not a scintilla of evidence to justify the increased valuation. In the face of the report of the Commission, the Minister should either produce evidence to justify his action, or acknowledge his mistake.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I other side prove their case.  any further time. I am satisfied that there is no justification for an increase of duty equivalent to Â£ $ 0 per machine, or 75 per cent. The direct and indirect protection now afforded to local manufacturers is quite sufficient, and I would not grant them one penny more. I would not give them a fraction more. I will vote with the honourable and learned member for Bendigo, believing that in doing so I am extending to the industry more protection than it really deserves. I need scarcely mention that one manufacturer connected with it has netted no less a sum than ,Â£34,000 during one year. An industry which can yield such returns ought to lie very well served by a fixed duty of ,Â£10 per machine.

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Bendigo) [5.1] By way of personal explanation, I should like to say that the Minister of Trade and Customs has seen fit to make a remark which seriously reflects not only upon the Tariff Commission, but upon myself as Chairman of that body. He has stated that he understood that witnesses were afraid to appear before the Commission

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I not only understood it, but I know it. names, if necessary.

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Minister stated that he understood that witnesses were afraid to come before the Commission lest they should be bullied and insulted, and be denied fair play. All I can say is that every witness who" came before us received a fair hearing. He was fairly ex-' amined as to his evidence-in-chief, and in the ordinary course he had to submit to cross-examination all round the table cross-examination by protectionists and free-traders alike. It is quite true that at times a witness may have been pressed severely by members of the Commission in the exercise of their undoubted rights. But whenever witnesses were frank in their answers they had no reason whatever to complain of being pressed unduly, and when ' they appealed for it they invariably received the protection of the Chair. I will say, on behalf of the free-trade members of the Commission, as well as the protectionist members of that body, that when-, ever the Chair decided in favour of a wit-' ness, he immediately received the consideration which the Chair directed should be extended to him. Although sometimes shall make the the protectionist, and at other times the free-trade, members of the Commission were severe in their cross-examination of witnesses, they always yielded to the Chair whenever the Chair appealed to them to give fair play to witnesses. Some witnesses wished to claim privilege, and did not want to answer questions-indeed , they had to be frequently appealed to by myself in that connection. I had occasion many times to point out that, in their own interests, they ought to give full answers to the questions put to them, otherwise they would probably suffer, and be prejudiced. In the course of their examination, some manufacturers positively .refused to give evidence regarding the cost of the production of their manufactures. They were willing to give private and confidential information, but, asChairman of the Commission, I declined to receive any information except such as we could publish to the whole world, and such as I could repeat upon the floor of the House.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hume-Minister of Trade and Customs) [5.5] - I ask' the indulgence of the Committee to make a personal explanation. I made a certatn interjection which has produced a statement from the Chairman of the Tariff Commission. In reply to his remarks, I I could give the say that I can give instances-on e in par'' ticular, in which a person - who was endeavouring to induce a man holding a very high position to give evidence before the Commission could not persuade him do so in consequence - as he said to number of people as well as to myself- the industry. of the bullying of witnesses by Senator ' Clemons.  duty by not reporting the matter to the that House.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It was published in the newspapers. The gentleman to whom I refer holds a very high position in New South Wales.

Speaker: Mr MCWILLIAMS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Who was it?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I can supply the name, if necessary. Though that gentleman was prepared to give evidence, he would not do so because he would not get consent to appear before the Commission to be bullied as certain witnesses had bullied in Victoria by Senator Clemons.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not think that ness should be proceeded with until this the matter has been investigated. Sir WILLIAM LYNE.'-Did not the honourable member read of it in the newsnaceous papers ?

Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: At any rate, this statement is true.

Speaker: Mr FISHER

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN

It does appear me that the Commission has done a very great deal of good work, inasmuch as demonstrated that many men are prone to make statements which they are not pared to substantiate upon oath. In Parliamentary lobbies some men are quite ready to make all sorts of statements which they are not willing to subscribe to upon oath. I think that.the Minister of Trade and Customs has shown very clearly that these individuals are not truthful, otherwise they would have appeared before the Comme mission and have given evidence. I say that the stripper-harvester industry appears ' to be a very flourishing one. No single to firm enjoys a monopoly of the trade.. In a Victoria there are sixteen firms engaged in

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS

Why do we not condemn the manufacturers of harvesters in it has New South Wales? If censure is to be administered, it should be apportioned all preround. The Tariff Commission has thothe roughly investigated this question-  Customs declares that it has not. He savs that witnesses feared to appear .before the Commission lest they should be bullied.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It appears to that the Commission were not warranted in investigating the claim of the manufacturers of stripper-harvesters as exhaustively as they did. 'But they have chosen to do so, and the evidence which they elicited conclusively proves that the local manufacturers of these machines are able to produce them at a cost of , Â£ 4 1 , including the cost of labour. An operator who is engaged in the industry informed the Commission that it cost ,Â£25 to produce a machine, and he estimated sundries at an additional Â£ 5 . But accepting the Commission's own figures as correct, the cost of manufacturing the stripper-harvester is ^ 4 1 , apart from an additional Â£ 2 1 for distribution. would make a total of Â£ 6 2 , and as these harvesters are sold to the farmers at ^ 8 0 , a clear profit of Â£ 1 8 is made upon the sale of each machine. In New South Wales and South Australia the manufacturers can make a profit of ,Â£18 2s. j d . on each machine. Surely that is a sufficient profit upon an outlay of Â£ 6 2 . Mr Martin stated that it cost him no more to produce his machine than it would cost elsewhere, and that he was willing to sell it for . Â£ 6 3 . admit that it was not the perfected machine of today, but, nevertheless, the cost of manufacturing it was quite as large. Honourable members must recollect that in twelve months the stripper-harvester will have been still further improved upon. Experience shows that when so improved, its cost of production will probably be less than it is at the present time. In these circumstances, why should the selling price be more than Â£ 6 0 ? When these machines were selling in South Australia at Â£ 7 0 was being charged for them in Victoria. The farmer is well able fo take care of himself if he is an unrestricted choice. He has the readv cash and. if fie is allowed buy in the cheapest market. sonable competition, the man who has chines to sell will be readv to dispose of them at a fair profit. There' may combination to keep up the price of vesters. Judging from the fact that a fit of /".iS per machine is being That accepting the figures as sworn to Companies' representatives, and accepting the expenses of an Australian-made stripper-harvester, merchandising profit on the Landing cost, including duty... Selling expenses Merchandising profit Selling price ... am inclined to think that there is. As one who has had considerable business experience, I am disposed to think that many people will be crowding into this industry if they are once satisfied that they can secure such a profit.

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Why is not the sewing machine industry crowded, since in that a profit of 300 per cent, is made ?

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: As a matter of fact, many firms have crowded into that industry, and different fields are allotted to them. The names of certain This makes of sewing machines are familiar to us in Australia, but when we go to other parts of the world we hear for the first time of entirely different brands. The position is the same in regard to the manufacture of agricultural implements and machinery. In Victoria machines that are not employed in New South Wales a.r<> used, and vice versa. At present there are sixteen firms producing these machines in Victoria, three in South Australia, and I five in New South Wales. I remember when the number was far less, and it seems probable that others will soon enter the industry, for a profit of ,Â£18 per machine is an excellent one. I can understand a protectionist arguing that an industry ought to be " put on its feet" as it were, and protected from competition abroad, where the cost of production is less. But the position is very different in regard to the harvester industry. The local manufacturer can compete with the foreign makers of these machines. According to the report of the Tariff Commission, a Massey-Harris machine costs jÂ£6o to given produce and land, and an International harvester, Â£$5, whilst locally the cost of to do so, will manufacture is Â£41. Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: ,Â£6 o is. 4d. is not the factory cost of the Massey-Harris machine.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is the factory cost plus freight and other expenses incurred in landing the machines in Australia.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Includin g the profit.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I shall say nothing about the profit, but the figures I have read cannot be disputed. The difference between the expenses incurred in selling these machines is certainly remarkable. I meet the - agents - all over New South Wales, and, so far as I can judge, there is very little difference between the expenses incurred by the travellers of the several firms. If anything, the agents of the Massey-Harris Company travel in better style, and yet, whilst their selling expenses amount to ,Â£17 16s. n d . per machine, that of the Australian manufacturers is -Â£21 17s. sd. An allowance of ,Â£17 f Â° selling expenses ought to be sufficient for anv manufacturer to work upon. The Government now proposes to impose a duty of ,Â£i6 per machine, and if that impost were added to the merchandising, profits already secured by the local manufacturers they would make a profit of Â£Z4 2s. 7d. on everv machine sold by them: I do not think, however, that the increased duty would be added to the present selling price. It seems to me that the proposal is practically one to prohibit the importation of harvesters, and that even the reduced duty of .Â£10 suggested by the Chairman of the Tariff Commission mav be regarded in the same light. If all 'that is desired is the imposition, of a protective duty, why should such an impost be proposed ? If , on the other hand, prohibition is desired, why stop at aduty of Â£ 1 0 per machine? Why not impose one"ofi .Â£50? I am satisfied that the introduction of American machines is advantageous to the local manufacturers, as well as to the farming community, since it compels the local makers to adopt up-to-date methods, and to produce an article equal to the imported one. The United States of America, with its population of 80.000.000, is the home of inventive genius. of an inventive turn of mind in the old country, being unable to secure that assistance which should be accorded them, emigrate to America, where they find scope for their genius. It is for this reason that the United States produces more improved machinery than does any other country. There is a field there for brains. Manufacturers there will improve on the machines that we bring out from time to time, and if we give them a chance to export to Australia our farmers will be advantaged. It seems to me, however, that both the Minister of Trade and Customs and the Chairman of the Tariff Commission desire to prohibit these imports, and that, if we are to Have prohibition, we might just as well vote for the motion as for the amendment foreshadowed by the honourable and learned member for Bendigo. That honourable member is a shrewd business man, who has presided in an admirable mariner over the deliberations of the Commission. If he thinks that there is an opportunity for the local manufacturers to add the increased duty to the price which they charge the farmers for their machines r

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Is it not proposed to provide that the price shall be reduced within two years to -Â£70?

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is a very plausible condition; but I would remind honourable members that one Parliament o cannot bind another any more than a Ministry can bind its successors in office. The local manufacturers will treat with disdain any proposal we may make as to the way in which they, shall manage their own business. They would be quite justified in doing so. What right have we to interfere and to sav that they shall reduce their prices? If we wish to secure reduced prices we should allow competition, to prevail.

Speaker: Mr HUTCHISON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Where was the competition during the reign of the combine?

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The combination in Australia was to keep up prices and prevent competition. There is, undoubtedly, an understanding amongst the manufacturers that the price of these machines shall not be reduced, because the rates prevailing in all the States are very similar. It is a common occurrence for business men to meet at their clubs and elf.ewhere, and when they do so they naturPeople ally discuss business matters. The tendency amongst them is to keep up the price of their products, and to keep down the pi ice of their raw material. We cannot regulate their trade. They have to pay their way, and to take risks; but, seeing that we have had in Australia a combination to prevent competition, is it reasonable that we should prevent the importation of machines by persons who are not in a ring?

Speaker: Mr HUTCHISON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The importers were in the combine.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I think that said a local manufacturer was in the combine.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: They were all in it.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Quite so. cost There is nothing novel in such a procedure. Bv-and-by, when we reach that socialistic state about which we have heard so much, we may hear no more of this system, and is just possible that when a member of a combine does something of which the others do not approve, the " fat will be in the fire," to use a colloquialism-and we shall cient protection. have competition, and reduced prices. What will the effect be? Will not the farmer be able to garner more wheat, to put larger quantities on Victorian to the market, and thus to sell at lower prices? But, if you put him to the pense to which he was formerly put. the price of your loaf will be increased. am not here to legislate for the primary producers as a class; but I point out that they pass on the benefits given to them, afford and enable the consuming public to pura chase more with its money. Those who member wish well to the masses of the people should make things easy for the primary producers. I think that a profit of Â£ 1 on a harvester is quite enough. The proThis posed duty would be prohibitive, and if , by prohibiting importation, we destroy competition, prices will keep up. Already chines have been sold for as little as Â£ 6 and, no doubt, the jealousies of the local manufacturers, caused by the endeavours to get ahead of one another by purchasing large lines of timber, by buying up tin in large quantities, and by paying higher wages than are agreed upon, in order to get better men, will from time to time cause a falling-out among them, as the result of which prices will go down. But that is not a reason why we should prevent competition from outside. Such competiit tion is likely to bring prices down to ^ per machine, and perhaps to an even lower sum. According to the Tariff Commission's report, ai number of farmers gave evidence in opposition to the proposal to increase the duty on stripper-harvesters. They dently' thought that the prices would increased if the duty was raised, and considered that the existing rate is suffifor ciently high.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I was among farmers last week, and they were all of the contrary opinion.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: One witness that it costs from ^ 1 4 to ^ 1 5 to bring a harvester from the factory in, North America to the warehouse in Australia. Is not that natural protection enough? He arrived at his estimate by considering the of setting up the machine, taking it to pieces, packing it, providing cases, paying freight by rail from the factory to the shop, paying freight by sea, and the exi t pense of insurance and landing in Australia. In the opinion of the farmers generally, according to the Tariff Commission, the local manufacturers ailready have suffiMr James MCGregor, who is a farmer, estimated the actual cost of turning out a machine fit for work at .Â£30, and, as an operator in one of the factories estimated the cost at Â£ 2 5 , showing how it was made up, Mr. exMCGregor was not far out. He told the Commission that, if Â£ 2 0 were added I to the cost of production to provide for the cost of marketing, and another Â£ 1 0 to provide a profit, the manufacturer could to sell at Â£ 6 0 , instead of at Â£ 8 i difference of over Â£ 2 0 . The honourable for Moira said last night that these machines would come down in price to Â£ 7 0 ; but his farming friends sav that 8 Â£ 6 0 would be a sufficiently high " price. is not the opinion of a'free-trader.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Yes , it is. Mr McmaGregor is the only pronounced free-trade 3 , farmer in that portion of my constituency and rivalries in which he lives.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am pleased to learn that there is a free-trade farmer in the honourable member's constituency. If all his constituents are as intelligent as is Mr MCGregor, he represents a very intelligent electorate. I hope that, at the next election, he will find that the number of free-traders in his division is larger than was at the last election. Very little has 6 3 been said by the protectionists on behalf of the farmers. They do-not appear to care much about the farmers. Is it because the farmers have fewer votes to give than those connected with large manufacturing centres ? eviTheir efforts are making things easy for be the 500,000 manufacturing people round they about Melbourne. The honourable member Gippsland made a speech last night which ought to weigh with every protectionist. He is a protectionist whom everv one respects, and told the Committee tihar, when Minister of Trade and Customs, he thought that more protection should be given to the harvester-making industry, But, having gone very thoroughly into the matter, he found that, on the information placed before him, he would not be justiried in increasing the protection now enjoyed by the manufacturers. He discovered that the local manufacturing industry is standing on its feet. It has arrived at that position in which, theoretically, it is the object of protection to place industries; it is able to stand alone, without needing to be bolstered up.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Wh v not sav nursed up?

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Eve n after industries are able to go alone, the protectionists are afiaid that they may fall and insist upon bolstering them up to keep them on their feet. The free-traders, on the other hand, say, Throw away the crutches. Let there be a fair field, and the local manufacturers will do well." As I have shown, the manufacturers of harvesters could make a profit of the price of their machines were only Â£ 6 0 each - used

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is pure assumption, since the Tariff Commission was not - able to obtain from the manufacturers all the figures necessary to determine the cost of their machines.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Every depart ment in a factory has to pay its way, just as every department in a soft-goods warehouse has to do so. The heads of the departments in these harvester factories have given evidence, upon which, in addition to the evidence tendered by the firms themselves, the Commissioners arrived at their conclusions.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Commissioners say that the manufacturers would not supply the facts which they wanted.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: They say that certain manufacturers would not produce their books to show the profits which they were making. Presumably those profits were so huge that the manufacturers are afraid that if they were known they could not obtain more protection. But the protectionists of Victoria vote foihigher duties, not because they are needed, but because that is the policy of the State, which the people drink in every morning, As the public here believe in protection, 'their representatives feel that they must give it to them, and therefore the country is poor compared with other countries where the people have more of the comforts and blessings of life, and are able to put by more for rainy davs. Of what use would it be for me to talk free-trade in the division of Moira ? But this is a national Parlia'ment, and, while the people of Victoria may ask for high duties, the farmers in other States do not believe in paving from 20 to 30 per cent, more for what they buy than is a fair price. The farmers in imconstituency think that they should not pay more than',Â£60 for harvesters, seeing that that price will give a good profit to the manufacturers. They do not like to be asked to pay ^ 8 1 when they know that a firm will sell three machines at Â£ 6 3 each. There are men in my constituency who could buy fiftv machines at a time.' The holdings in Victoria and South Australia are small compared with the immense areas I ! under cultivation in New South Wales. The honourable member for Moira last night referred to the time when that State could not produce sufficient grain for its own or more i l requirements, and seemed to spurn it for that reason; but I remember when Victoria to get its grain from South Australia. and when, even earlier, South Australia used to get its grain from Chili.

Speaker: Mr HUTCHISON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: We have found out how foolish we were.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is better to get grain from Chili than to go without flour; and everything must have a begin ning. Every year the farmers of New South Wales are adding to their cultivation areas, and before long that State will be able to supply breadstuffs for the whole Commonwealth. It already supplies its own requirements, and has an export trade. The people of New South Wales did not go into wheat-growing formerly, because they could make more money in other ways.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: They could never make as much money per acre from wool as they have made from wheat.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Perhaps not: but what they considered was their total income. In some parts of New South Wales there is now intense culture, and what were sheep-walks have been found to contain good agricultural land. In the earlv davs however, sheep-raising paid better than anv' thing else, and therefore the people in the country districts stuck to sheep. Now that they can make more monev by <*rowin <Â»rain e they are bringing larger" area's under cultivation. They are carrying on operations on the same large scale as the farmers of California and Canada. There is no justification for prohibiting the importation of stripper-harvester's. It would be against the best interests not only of the consumers, but of the manufacturers themselves, to shut out the imported machines. Our object should be to obtain a perfect machine. The stripper-harvester in use today will not answer our purposes ten years heiice. Our producers have to compete in the markets of the world with the farmers of Canada and the United States, and unless we are able to give our settlers the most up-to-date appliances they will be placed at a great disadvantage. A duty of Â£ 1 6 would undoubtedly prevent the importation of stripper-harvesters from abroad, because it would not be possible to add the duty to the present price. The. machines are sold at as high a price as the farmers can afford to pav. and there is no likelihood of their submitting to an increase of rates. The manufacturers would, no doubt, obtain ^ 9 0 per machine as formerly if they could, but they know jhat the farmers would not stand such an imposition. The Government did not come into power as prohibitionists, and I do not think that they would be justified in imposing prohibitive duties.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Coul d the honourable member sav what reduction was made in the cost of machines when the duty was reduced ?

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Busines s cannot be regulated in the way that the honourable member's question suggests. manufacturer will reduce his price for various reasons. He may want money to meet his obligations at the end ofi the quarter, and he may bring down the price of his wares in order to turn them into cash. Sometimes his banker orders him to sell off his stock in order that he mayobtainmoney with which to reduce his overdraft. All manufacturers have not large banking accounts or unlimited credit, and I know that many of them have a hard struggle to make ends meet. I think, however, that we shall do the best thing for the manufacturer as well as for the consumer by imposing only a fair duty. Mr MCKay sends his machines away to the Argentine. He states that if he did not get rid of his surplus in that way he would have to dismiss his men and shut down his works. He sells' his machines in the Argentine at a profit, but he would sell them all the same if he did not make any profit. It appears that, during the first seven months of this year, he has sold 'fifty more machines than during last year. It may be said that Mr MCKay dumps his machines into the Argentine in order to clear the market and make more money out of the local consumers. We must not take any notice of the bald assertion of the prices being brought down when duties are reduced. We are interfering too much with the manufacturers, and making things harder for the producers. We should not deprive ourselves of the opportunity to take advantage of the brains of American inventors and manufacturers. It would be against the interests of the farmers and of the whole community to do so. It must be remembered that South Australia, Victoria, and New South Wales are now exporting grain to the old country, and that our producers must keep themselves abreast of the times in order to successfully compete in the world's markets. The idea of the local manufacturers, apparently, is that the high duty will prevent the importation of harvesters from abroad, and enable them to obtain a higher price for their machines. The honourable member for Moira told us that the farmer had no right to complain, because, among other things, he obtained his land on time payment. But I would point out that the farmer buys his land on credit, and pays interest upon the principal until he has completed the purchase. Therefore, it cannot be urged that he is placed in any position of special advantage in that reA gard. The honourable member pointed out also that the farmer had received the advantage of technical education provided by the State. What does that mean? If by means of technical education the farmer is shown how to grow ears of wheat containing 120 grains as against 60 grains formerly produced, he will be able to grow a larger quantity, and as a result prices will be brought down, and the general community will Be benefited. The farmer may iDe benefited by the increased output, but the consumer will also derive considerable advantage, and the little ones belonging to poor families in the old land will get more to eat.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The landlords derive the advantage. The agricultural labourer in England is no better off today than he was fifty years ago.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The whole community benefits. The land-owner is no doubt just as bad as the manufacturer. It must be understood, however, that he, as well as others, has to submit to competition. The honourable member for Moira also told us that railway freights in Victoria and New South Wales were reduced for the benefit of the farmer. They were reduced in order to encourage the farmer to put more land under cultivation and to provide more traffic and freight for railways. If I had my way, a great deal of the produce grown in the far distant parts of the country would be carried at a loss, in prder to encourage the settlers to bring larger areas under cultivation. If the reduced rates had the desired effect, the railways would be amply repaid by the greater volume of traffic that would be carried over the lines in the future. The railways of South Australia have been the best managed in the Commonwealth, because they have been worked on commercial lines. The railway authorities of South Australia have afforded every encouragement to the settlers in the back'blocks beyond Goyder's line of rainfall, where the crops no not produce more than three or four bushels per acre. Many farmers of South Australia have told me that at times they have been on the verge of starvation, and have not been' able to obtain sufficient food for their little ones. railways, however, which have been extended far into the interior, have rroved a great boon to them, and have lightened their burdens very considerably. Foi instance, there is the railway to Farina, extending hundreds of miles into the interior. If the Government were to charge the farmers beyond Goyder's line of rainfall the same rate that they charge the men who are settled within ten or twenty miles of Adelaide, they would drive them off the land. It is necessary to open up railways to develop the country. By so doing we secure a greater volume of trade. We obtain more breadstuffs, and we bestow more blessings upon the communitv as a whole. MT-. BATCHELOR - But wheat is not grown at Oodnadatta.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am aware of that. Oodnadatta is in the centre of Australia-in the arid portion of the continent. I can recollect the time when the South Australian railway terminus was at Terowie, and when the railway system of that State was altered to the 3' ft. 6 in. gauge and extended to districts where the production of cereals was very much less per acre than it was in the more favoured spots. The South Australian Government has been constantly extending its railways beyond the area within which cereals are produced. Of course, I know that grain can be grown there successfully. One has only to read the articles which the honourable member for Echuca has contributed to the Argus newspaper to appreciate what the can be accomplished by means of the system of dry farming, which really resolves itself into the conservation of the natural moisture by earth mulching. I hold that something should be done for the producer. He does not get any consideration to which he is not entitled. Everything that he gets is passed on to the consumer, and competition regulates the prices.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: There is no fund other than that which is contributed by the people.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Exactly . The source of all wealth is the land. We can have no prosperity in the country if we injure the primary producers. Consequently I ask, " Are we going to give the manufacturers all the benefits which accrue from improved methods of agriculture? Are we going to assist them to make profits amounting to ;Â£io,ooo, ^20,000 and even The ,Â£30,000 annually?" It seems to me that the policy of the Government is to impose a prohibitive duty upon stripper-harvesters and other agricultural implements and machinery. That, I contend, is a most improper thing to do. Ministers have no mandate from the country to give effect to such a policy, and I hope that, when they appeal to the electors, they will receive a lesson which will prevent them from again bringing forward similar proposals.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: WideBay^ [6.3] - The question under consideration has been presented to honourable members in many aspects. The last speaker has adopted a line of reasoning of his own, which I do not propose to follow, beyond saying-in regard to his statement concerning the benefits which have been derived in Great Britain by reason of the adoption of improved methods of agriculture-that , in my opinion, those benefits have not been reaped by the persons who ought to have enjoyed them. The employees have not benefited to the extent that they should have done. They have not received the remuneration which really belonged to them as the result of the improved methods of labour which" have been applied to the cultivation of the soil. But we are now called upon to decide whether the duty upon stripper-harvesters shall be Â£ 1 0 or jQx6 per machine. In myopinion, the amendment submitted by the honourable member for Lang is an impracticable one. No doubt he has introduced it for the purpose of giving effect to his particular views; but I know of no means by which it would be possible to distribute the increased duty proposed in the way that he suggests. Honourable members of the Opposition have frequently pointed out the great advantages Which are enjoyed by the sugar growers of Queensland as the result of legislation enacted by this Parliament. The honourable member for New England has often complained of the payment of the bounty to the growers who produce sugar hi Australia exclusively by white labour. I wish to ask him whether he will adopt the same course in regard to stripper harvesters that has been adopted in the case of the sugar industry ? Personally I am prepared to extend to the manufacturers of stripper-harvesters even more generous treatment than has been meted out to the sugar-growers. I am quite willing, to support a proposal under which the Government will be enabled to levy an Excise upon these machines equal to half the amount of Customs duty, and I am further prepared to legislate in the direction of securing the return of the whole of that Excise duty to the employers who will conform to the awards of Wages Boards and Arbitration Courts. If in any State these institutions do not exist. I am quite willing that the Excise should be returned to the employers who comply with the awards of the Wages Boards or of the Arbitration Court in the adjoining State. But I would prevent any other employer from participating in the bounty. I put this suggestion before the Committee in the hope that I may educate certain honourable members who have been complaining of the sugar industry.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am opposed t'o granting the manufacturers an increased duty for the purpose of levying an Excise.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not object to the honourable member's view. But, assuming that the Committee agree to the increased duty proposed, what will he do? Some reference was made by the honourable member for Melbourne Ports to the effect that Federal Tariff has had upon the iron industry in Queensland. He quoted figures to show that there had been a decrease in the number of employees in that industry since the establishment of Federation. That decrease was inevitable. But it was not the result of the operation of the Federai Tariff. It was due to the competition of Victoria, and other States, whose industries were better established. I suppose that the honourable member would be surprised to learn that shipping companies carry machinery from Melbourne to the north of Queensland for less freight than is charged for carrying it from Maryborough to Townsville, which is only a fraction of the distance?

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Are there increased wharfage charges at either place?

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No . A perusal of the report of the Shipping Commission will disclose the reason for this state'of things. The shipping combination can practically wipe out a small port. It can prescribe conditions regarding rebates which effectually prevent manufacturers from sending machinery by any boats other than its own. Upon every consignment of cargo carried by the combine a secret rebate of io per cent, is granted. Thus, if a manufacturer traded with a small schooner, he would by that innocent act sacrifice the whole of the rebate that would otherwise accrue to him. These cojnditioins have militated against the expansion of the iron industry in Queensland more than has the Tariff. I do not say that the Tariff which Parliament passed extended sufficiently high duties to the iron .industry. In my opinion, those duties should have been much higher. Personally, I am of opinion that the iron industry should be nationalized. Another factor which has materially affected foundries in Queensland is that about the time of the establishment of the Federation, the Government railway workshops were established at Ipswich. This naturally deprived the foundry there of a large amount of work. Queensland's loan policy came to an end. and that end brought many changes.  State free-trade was established.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Quite so; I shall refer presently to that point. With the cessation of its loan policy, Queensland had less money available than it had before for the - construction of railways, bridges, and other the public works, including sugar mills. T may say, in passing, that the people of that State, through the Government, have loaned over Â£500,000 to the sugar growers to provide the machinery necessary to enable them to get their produce to market. The point is often overlooked that a mill costing something like Â£50,000 is necessary to the successful production of sugar, and that whe.e the area under sugar cane is not sufficient to justify the erection of a mill of that capacity, a crop is practically worthless. The cessation of the State borrowing policy, interfered with the erection of large mills and the carrying out of many public works, whilst the establishment of Inter-State free-trade enabled the ironfounders of other States, and mora particularly of Victoria, to enter into serious competition with the local manufacturers. Although I have not the figures at hand, I am clearly of opinion that the number of hands employed in the iron industry has not increased in proportionto the increase in the output. The capacity of a worker is increased from time to time by the .introduction of improved machinery, so that, whilst the output of an industry may increase, the number of hands engaged in it may concurrently be reduced. That is a well known feature of industrial life  riveting machine, for instance, has duced the field of employment in the iron trade.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is so. By means of a small hydraulic machine, two men things. are now able to do what was previously the work of ten. I presume that honorwho able members do not regret the introduction of labour-saving appliances. It is said that improvements in machinery lessen the field of employment, but I that that contention is altogether correct. It should not be the ambition of an intelliamendment gent democratic Parliament simply to make ber for Lang? work for the people. It should rather be our desire to see that every person who willing to engage in useful labour shall ceive a wage sufficient to enable him to into operation. live in comfort and to enjoy a few of the luxuries of life. If that, we ought to make room for others who nave some tangible and learned practicable ideas on the subject. Unize fortunately, however, the Commonwealth Parliament has not the power to inforce wages conditions. Although, as the Prime Minister has said, the framers of the stitution " builded better than they knew," I think, in this respect, the instrument is defective.^ The Parliament which has the power to impose Customs and Excise duties is the only effective body to determine what shall be the wage conditions in the industries to which those duties apply.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: An amendment of the Constitution would soon remedy the trouble.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am glad that the Opposition are not entirely opposed to such a proposition.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hear , hear.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: To use a well-known Australian term,, the Parliament, when imposing duties, is " hobbled" by the fact that it is not free to enact that those employed in the industries to which they relate shall not be in a worse position than they were before. Whilst some of the States Parliaments have devised various means to insure the payment of fair wages and the observance of reasonable conditions of labour, others, unfortunately, have made no such provision for the protection of the workers. In some cases high duties have had a mischievous effect.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The v have not helped the wage earners.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Whils t high duties have the been imposed the wage earners have been reneglected. But of recent vears a new principle, that of "the new'protection." has come into plav.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is the oldest of old

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I understand that those support it desire that the manufacturer, who is benefited by the imposition of protective duties shall distribute amongst his employees a fair proportion of the addo not think vantage so obtained.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is the effect of the moved by the honoiable mem

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If such an amendment is were passed it would be futile. The Comremonwealth has no machinery to bring it

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Then the duties would not we cannot do come into operation.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable and member would be the last to penala good man. I would remind him that, although the great bulk of those engaged in thrt industry were readv and willing to pay fair wages, and to have regard to reasonConable conditions of labour, these duties under the amendment would not come into operation if one manufacturer refused to do so.

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The amendment is absurd. It would not touch the question.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I think it would be futile.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Does the honourable member agree with the statement of the Minister of Trade and Customs that the members of the Commission were grossly unfair to witnesses?

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not, and I regretted to hear the Minister make it . I am sure that if the honourable gentleman had given the matter a moment's consideration, he would not have made such a seriouÂ« statement.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I have the newswould paper containing a full statement of whole matter.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I know that the able gentleman, whose goodness of heart one will deny, speaks at times rather bluntly, and I think that, in this instance, he expressed himself rather roughly.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I did not reflect the slightest degree upon the Chairman the Commission.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I cannot endorse that statement.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: But I did not.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not wish to disbe cuss the question. I have already that I think the members of the CommisGovernment sion have done a great work. lived through manv laborious days.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I quite admit that.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The v have struggled, dare sav, through laborious nights, do not think that any Commission ought be empowered to bring down specific provested posals as to the duties which should posed.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I quite agree with the honourable member that such recomin. mendations are altogether outside the prowith technical points. . vince of a Commission.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I should not find fault with a Government which refused to notice of such recommendations. mission appointed by the Crown has none of the responsibilities of the Executive. might bring down, proposals for the imposiI tion of certain duties which, if adopted, would deprive the Executive of the revenue necessary to carry on the administration the country.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Commission has merely made recommendations to the Parliament.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The terms of their appointment are very limited. The Commission was appointed to inquire into the effects of the Tariff, and its business was to report in general terms upon the result of their investigation.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: To diagnose the disease and not to suggest the remedy?

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is for this Parliament to prescribe the remedy. Silting suspended from 6.30 to 7.30 p.m.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member for Corinella has asked, in effect, what be the use of the investigations of the the Commission if it did not make definite and distinct recommendations. I am honorsurprised at such a question from so no acute a mind. The Commissioners were appointed to inquire into the effects, good, bad, or indifferent, c f the present Tariff. It would have been sufficient for in them to report that certain industries were of becoming lean and attenuated and others too f at and prosperous. While they might have indicated the remedy for both diseases-becaus e it is as bad for the body politic that industries should be too lean as it is that they should be too fat-it would for Parliament to prescribe the remedy said to be applied. I have Dointed out that a might be deprived of revenue They have as the effect of a report of a Commission. That of course is a side issue; but, undoubtedly, the action of a Commission in I making definite proposals may be a source but I of embarrassment to a Government. The to power to increase Customs valuations is in the Minister of Customs; but it be imshould be most sparingly exercised, and when exercised, opportunity should be given to those aggrieved to test the matter a Court of law without being met In my opinion, there is nothing more dangerous than to allow the Executive to increase duties at take will. This should be done only by the A Comdirect vote of Parliament. While I do not impugn the motives of the Minister of It Trade and Customs or of the Government, say that a democratic Parliament should guard with the greatest jealousy its right to impose taxation. I shall support the of recommendation of the Tariff Commission, not because it is their recommendation, but because, - in my opinion, the evidence permits of no other course being taken. No information has been laid before "us indicating that a fixed duty higher than Â£ 1 0 a machine is necessary. But as this Parliament desires to benefit the workmen as well as the manufacturers, and as it cannot appoint Wages Boards to determine questions of remuneration and conditions of employment, I think that the imposition of an Excise duty amounting to half of the import duty ..should be agreed to, giving a bounty of the same amount in every case where a manufacturer conforms with the conditions prescribed by a Wages Board or an Arbitration Court, or, where there is no such authority, pays the rate of wages which is the mean between the rates so prescribed. If this is done, our legislation will benefit the workers as well as the manufacturers.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Boothby) [7.36]I am very glad that the honourable member for Wide Bay has brought the discussion back to the amendment, to which I propose to confine my remarks. The general debate has been useful, but it will be wise for us now to focus our attention on the point raised by the amendment of the honourable member for Lang.

Speaker: Mr HUTCHISON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That amendment is farcical.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I admit that the honourable member's proposal is impracticable, and cannot be seriously considered; but I assume that his object is that the workmen in protected industries shall share with the employers the benefits obtained from duties, an object with which - all honourable members must be in sympathy. I ask the Committee to try to devise some scheme which will achieve that object. Notwithstanding the platform utterances of some honourable members, who suggest that the protectionists seek merely to fatten a few manufacturers, we know they credit us with the belief that good wages, short hours, and healthy conditions are more likely to be obtained for workmen under protection than under free-trade. Unfortunately, however, the workmen have not always participated in the benefits which have accrued, by reason of the imposition of the duties, to the industries with which they have been connected. I question very much whether the benefits given to the stripper-harvester industry by protection have been' fairly shared by the men engaged in' it. The fact that the largest manufacturer of stripper-harvesters in Australia moved his works to Bray brook in order to esca.ce having to comply with the conditions laid down by a Victorian Wages Board shows that manufacturers are not always ready to fall in with the desire of a majority of the people that the workmen shall share fairly in the benefits of protection.

Speaker: Mr FRAZER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Mr MCKay has denied that he moved to Braybrook to evade having to comply with the conditions of a Wages Board.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If he wished to be brought under a Wages Board, he could easily agitate for that to be done, and, no doubt, would be successful. I have been termed a weak-kneed protectionist; but I shall be still more weak-kneed unless I receive an assurance that what obtained immediately after the passing of the last Tariff will not be allowed to continue. I was prepared to impose pretty high duties on many articles, but became weak-kneed in regard to protection when I saw how some manufacturers, and some of those who were very prominent in advocating the new protectionist doctrines, neglected to fulfil their obligations directly they received, or were certain of receiving, the benefits of protection. I happened to be the chairman of the inaugural meeting held at the Town Hall, Adelaide, at which the Protectionist Association of South Australia was formed, about a year prior to the establishment of the Commonwealth. At that meeting the new protectionist programme was adopted as the policy of the party in South Australia. That programme included the passing of a Factories and Shops Act, containing provisions relating to Wages Boards and arbitration, and so on. The principle underlying the policy was that the workmen, as well as the manufacturers, should share in the advantages of any protection that might be granted.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Where does the consumer come in ?

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am now dealing with the question from the point of view of the producers-the manufacturers and their workmen. The question of where the consumer comes in is another matter, which I do not wish to consider just now. M*r. MCWILLIAMS - It is a very important question.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I admit that. It must be acknowledged that the prices of many articles- I do not say all-upo n which duties have been imposed, have not been increased as the result of the protection accorded to the local manufacturer. Where there is strong local competition and a sufficiently large output, the tendency is to reduce prices, and to thus confer benefit upon the consumers. The manufacturers and workmen, of which the Protectionist Association was composed, worked together loyally until the Federal elections were held. Just prior to that time the Holder Administration succeeded in passing through both Houses a Bill upon the lines of the Victorian Factories and Shops Act, providing for the establishment of Wages Boards in connection with certain trades. Legislative Council inserted a provision that the regulations made under the Act should be laid upon the table of both Houses, and that if disallowed by either House, should not become operative. The Federal elections were held, and the majority of the candidates elected were protectionists. Towards the close of the Tariff debate in this Parliament, the regulations under the South Australian Factories Act were disallowed by the Legislative Council. No particular reason was advanced, but it appeared that some manufacturers, having attained one of the objects for which the Protectionist Association was formed, desired to prevent the introduction of the Wages Board system. I do not accuse the manufacturers of having directly caused the disallowance of the regulations, but the Chamber of Manufactures did its best to prevent the passing of the regulations, and further, when somewhat later a Commission was appointed to take evidence in Victoria as to the working of the Wages Board system, it requested the affiliated body in Melbourne to bring forward the strongest evidence possible against "the Wages Board system. If the manufacturers had desired to carry out their share of the compact, as members of the Protectionist Association, they might have petitioned the Legislative Council to allow the Wages Board regulations to pass, and thus bring the conditions in the State into line with those obtaining in Victoria, New South Wales, and Western Australia. From that day to this there have been no Wages Boards in South Australia, and whatever advantage has accrued from the protection given by the Tariff has been derived by the manufacturers alone. Although I believe in protection, I do not propose to give one fractional part of a percentage of additional protection to any industry until I can feel assured that the workman will receive a fair share of the advantage conferred.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Does the honourable member think that sufficient provision is made under the Government's proposal ?

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No ; I propose to ask the Committee to adopt conditions similar to those which have already been foreshadowed by the honourable member for Wide Bay-condition s which seem to be fair and workable. I do not agree with the proposal that any manufacturer who The fails to pay his workmen a fair and reasonable rate of wages shall pay Excise equal to the Customs duty levied on the imported article.
