text: But is the honourable member a free-trader any longer? , Mr Wilks - I say, again, in answer to the honourable member for Melbourne Ports, that while I consider that it is lowest and most despicable thing in politics lo look for loot from the public, that is to be the policy of Australia, I am not going to be foolish enough to stand aside and see industries in my electorate suffer without making an effort on their half. My experience in this Parliament shows me that in the opinion of too many stage. protectionists it is only the industries of Victoria that are to be looked after, whilst those of Australia generally may "go While I do not believe in the principle of taxing the people for the benefit of private interests, I certainly do say that if protection is to be the fixed policy of Australia I am going to take my share in putting in claims, though I regret that politics in this country should have come down to this level. Returning to the matter of harvesters, the position in regard to them is very much like that with respect to sewing machines, which are produced for Â£ 4 , whilst the user has to pay Â£ 1 5 . Apparently the same practice is in vogue in regard to harvesters. No one can contend that 25s. a week is a fair wage for a journeyman, to say nothing, of an improver. It is only sufficient for an apprentice. If this a duty of 25 per cent, be imposed, shall vote on every occasion for the workers in the industry getting their fair of the protection thus afforded. The are doing remarkably well as it is, and I do not see why the Parliament should make a further gift to them. I rebegret the bad treatment which kindred trades have received from the Government, to and I did expect that some protectionist members would rise to say a few words on I protest against the neglect of other industries while a small inwas dustry like that of agricultural implement making in Victoria is receiving this atten

Speaker: Sir LANGDON BONYTHON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Barker) [3.52] - At this late hour I am not to detain the Committee. I rise merely to explain that I am not prepared to follow the Government in imposing a duty of Â£ 1 6 unper machine; but I am quite ready to give the harvester manufacturers a protection of 25 per cent. The whole question turns of course upon the valuation. In my opinion, Â£ 6 5 is an excessive valuation. I am disposed to believe that the South Australian manufacturer who put the value down at about Â£ 4 0 gave a fair estimate. But out of consideration for the Ministry, the and as a loyal Ministerialist, I am prepared to stretch a point and to vote for a still, if fixed duty of Â£ 1 2 . Amendment negatived.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Parramatta) [3-53]-- I understood that the amendment beof which the honourable member for Wide Bay gave notice was to be moved at this

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK

text: If it is not going to be moved it is all right. I move That the following words be added to the item " Stripper-harvesters Â£16 " :-" and on and after 7th September, 1906, 12^ per cent, ad valorem."

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: On a point of order, sir, if you accept the amendment of the honourable member for Parramatta, and it is rejected, will it then be possible for honourable members to move for the imposition of higher duties until the proposed duty of Â£ 1 6 is reached?

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I think that if the Committee reject an amendment that on and after the 7th September the duty shall be 12J per cent., an honourable member can then move that on and after the 8th September it shall be 15 per cent., and soon.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If the amendment of the . honourable member for Parramatta be defeated, it will be competent for an honourable member to move for the imposition of any duty which he may think proper, either higher or lower than 12J per cent. That is the practice which was followed when the Tariff was being considered.  understood that the honourable member for Boothby was to move the amendment of which the honourable member for Wide Bay gave notice. If it is in order, sir, I shall move the amendment.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: As I have not yet put the amendment of the honourable member for Parramatta from the Chair, the honourable member will be quite in order in moving the amendment to which he refers.

Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Moira) [4.7]-- I do not wish to protract the debate

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The whole matter is open to discussion, and I desire an explanation of this proposal.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not wish to express an opinion as to the rights of any honourable member. What I desire to know is whether this amendment, if carried) will determine the question of whether a fixed or an ad valorem duty shall be imposed ?

Speaker: Sir LANGDON BONYTHON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Barker) [4.8] - I wish to know, Mr Chairman, whether I shall be in order in moving, 12 after this amendment has been disposed of, 32 that on and after the 7 th instant, the duty be Â£ 1 2 ? 20

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If the amendment AYES. moved by the honourable and learned member for Bendigo be carried, it will not be competent for the honourable member for Barker to move that which he has indicated. If , on the other hand, the amendment now before the Chair be negatived, he will be able to submit it.

Speaker: Sir LANGDON BONYTHON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Would it not be better to allow my amendment be first submitted to the decision of the .Committee ?

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Certainl y not.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Barrier) [4.9] - We factory have had a lengthy debate on the question of whether the cost of the imported harsent vester in the country of origin is Â£ 6 5 Â£ 3 8 . I voted against the last amendment ported machines. because I was following the lead of the Chairman of the Tariff Commission, who, I understood, intended to propose that a Court. fixed duty of Â£10-whic h I was led to believe was equivalent to a duty of 25 cent, on a valuation of Â£38-shoul d be imposed.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: They will not-be made here for Â£ 3 8 .

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Who is to determine the valuation ? If the decision is fo rest with the Minister, then an ad valorem duty of 25 per cent, will mean whatever he tion at Â£ 6 5 . chooses to make it. The honourable gentleman has valued these machines for Customs purposes at Â£ 6 5 , but has given the mittee no proof that that valuation is correct. I thought that the honourable and learned member for Bendigo was going to move for a fixed duty of Â£ 1 0 per machine. If agree to an ad valorem duty of 25 per cent., and the Minister insists upon a of Â£ 6 5 , the rate charged will be really 40 per cent, on what the Tariff Commission says is the cost price.

Speaker: Mr MCWILLIAMS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Minister cannot do that after the evidence which has published.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Bu the is doing it. I think that we should have some from the honourable and learned member for Bendigo. Some of us have already voted matter, I moveunder a misapprehension.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Is the honourable member going to follow the protectionist members of the Tariff Commission ?

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Yes , when it suits me to do so.

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Bendigo) [4.13] At the beginning of the discussion I intimated that I intended to propose a fixed duty of Â£ 1 0 per machine, which would be equivalent to an ad valorem duty of 25 per cent, on the factory price of Â£ 3 8 ; but, the honourable members for Echuca and Corinella and others said they would prefer an ad valorem rate, I yielded to their suggestion. I admit that there is more certainty about the fixed rate; but the proposal' now before the Committee will carry out to the recommendation of the Tariff Commission, and I am not wedded to either form of duty. I intend, however, that the proposed ad valorem duty shall be levied on a price of Â£ 3 8 , plus the statutory 10 per cent, increase. Litigation is at prepending in the Law Courts for the puror pose of determining the value of the imMr .MCCAY - The Minister ought to undertake to abide by the decision of the

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I apprehend that per it will be binding upon him, and that he will refuse to abide by it at the peril of his office. If I thought that the proposed ad valorem duty would not be levied on the valuation which I have mentioned, I would insist on a fixed duty; but I assumethat the evidence is so overwhelming that no Minister would dare to fix the valua

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Parramau^ [4.15] - It is useless for honourable memCombers to shelter themselves behind the plea that the Court will fix the valuation. The Minister is the man who will do that.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Opposition should we have moved a motion of want of confidence in the Government if they thought that the valuation Minister's action was wrong.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I agree - with the honourable member. We refrained from doing so because of the uselessness of the proceeding. The Committee believes now been that the value of the imported machines in Canada is Â£ 3 8 .

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Committee explanation does not believe that.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: To test the That the amendment be amended by adding the words, " On a basis of ^41 value." The CHAIRMjAN - I suggest that the honourable member should not move that amendment until the honourable member for Barker has been given an opportunity to test his proposal to make the duty Â£ 1 2 .

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If the amendment of the honourable member for Parramatta is carried, the amendment of the honourable member for Bendigo as amended will be as put, and if rejected, the honourable member for Barker can then move his amendment. On the other hand, if the amendment of the honourable member for Parramatta is negatived, the amendment of the honourable and learned member for Bendigo will be put, and, if negatived, the honourable member for Barker will still have his opportunity.

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I wish to call attention to the fact that the honourable member for Barker rose and had commenced to move his amendment when he was interrupted, and gave way to other honourable members. He is therefore clearly entitled to move his amendment first, if he so desires.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It has "been the practice throughout this discussion to permit the lower duty to be voted on first. Practically the duty will be the same whether the.amendment of the honourable member for Barker, or the two amendments which are now befoie the Chair are carried.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Do I understand that the amendment of the honourable member for Parramatta is open to discussion?

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Yes ; I was about to reply to the honourable member; for Corinella, who stated that in the event of the amendment before us being rejected, it would be competent for the honourable member for Barker to still submit his amendment. The amendment proposed by the honourable member for Parramatta is an amendment on the amendment proposed by the honourable and learned member for Bendigo; so that in the event I have indicated, it will be still competent for the honourable member^"for Barker fo submit his proposal.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Bland) [4.21] - I hope the Committee will not take such an unwise action as to tie the hands of this Committee or the Customs Department for manv years ahead. In any case, the valuation of stripper-harvesters varies, in common with the valuation of every other kind of commoditv. from year to year, according to circumstances and the cost of production. To adopt the proposal of the honourable member for Parramatta would mean that we fix what the valuation of stripper-harvesters is to be; and that seems to me to be absolutely ridiculous.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: There has been a Commission to fix the valuation as a matter of evidence.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Eve n if a Commission reported tomorrow that the valuation was Â£ 6 5 in Canada, that would not settle the valuation for the following year.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Does anvbodv believe the evidence that the valuation is Â£ 6 5 in Canada ?

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I have not the remotest idea of what the value of a stripper-harvester is in Canada, and I do not believe that any one in this House, not even the members of the Tariff Commission, have any idea.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Does the honourable member think that it is a higher value than in Australia ?

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not suppose that it is, but it is hard to ascertain. The manufacturers in Canada can consign their goods from their factory to their agents here, and, as it were, sell to themselves, so that it is not a transaction in ordinary business that can be examined.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am quite prepared to meet the honourable member on that point, and to add the words " until the Court has decided the value."

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is a very ingenious suggestion; but the honourable member for f arramatta ought to. be aware that there is no provision in the Customs Act for a Court fixing the values, of articles proposed to be imported.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I thought there was.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Not at all.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Why is a case before the Court now?

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am not prepared to sav why a case has been taken before the Court.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: In order to expose the dishonesty of the Minister.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I wish to say that if the honourable member for Werriwa were honest he would not, in this way, charge the Minister with dishonesty. It is most outrageous on the part of the honourable member.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Order . I have repeatedly called the honourable member for Werriwa to order, and he has disregarded the authority of the Chair. I must ask the honourable member to apologise to the Committee, and to cease his interjections.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I must admit, of course, that conduct like this is not parliamentary; but we must remember that, after all, there is a good deal of excitement over this matter, and some of us believe there has been a swindle.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Order ; the honourable member must withdraw and apologise to the Committee.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I apologise to the Com^ mittee for my interjection just now.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member must withdraw the statement he has made in reference to the Minister of Trade and Customs.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I feel that I would rather go out of the House.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Will the honourable member withdraw it?

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Well , I withdraw it.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I wish to say emphatically that if the honourable member for Werriwa has any charge against the Minister of Trade and Customs, or any other Minister, it is his duty to make that charge on the floor of the House, in clear and tinct language, so that the charge may be investigated and proved or disproved. That is the fair and honest thing to do. : Mr. JOSEPH COOK - I rise to a point of order. ' Mr WATSON - I am sick of these insinuations !

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I rise to a point of order. It is a rule of Parliament that an honourable member may not refer to a statement that has been withdrawn, and I object to the honourable member for Bland pursuing this line of argument.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I was not referring merely to the statement made by the honourable and learned member for Werriwa a moment or two ago, but to the continual references and insinuations of that honourable member. If the honourable and learned member has any charge to make, it is his duty to lay the evidence in support of it before Parliament and the country. If the honourable member has no evidence, he ought to - be manly enough to make no charge.

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I desire to have your ruling, Mr Chairman, as to whether the honourable member for Bland is doing right in pursuing this matter after the remark has been withdrawn and an apology made?

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I understand that the honourable member for Bland is referring to some other statement which I did not hear. If the honourable member for Bland has heard such a statement, he has a perfect right to refer to it.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: This arises out of an episode earlier in the evening.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I was not referring to the interjection of the honourable and learned member for Werriwa a few moments ago. The honourable member can take an opportunity to make any charge he thinks necessary.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Is the Minister of Trade and Customs not quite capable of defending himself?

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is for the Minister of Trade and Customs to decide. I am now speaking as an individual, and I say

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I rise to a point of order. I submit that the honourable member for Bland is not now discussing the question before the Chair, and I ask that he be directed to do so.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I ask the honourable member for Bland to direct his attention dis- to the question before the Chair.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That , I admit, is a valid point of order. What I was urging was that it would be altogether unwise to tie the hands of the Customs Department as to the valuation to be placed upon harvesters, or any other commodity which it was sought to import.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: There is the fixed duty.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The fixed duty is quite another matter, with which I shall deal in a moment. I am now referring to the fixing of the value of a commodity for the purpose of imposing an ad valorem duty. We might as well fix a value for boots and shoes, or any other commodity which is imported. I point out to the honourable member for Parramatta, and other honourable members who may dissent from the decision of the Minister in regard to the valuation of harvesters, that there is a parliamentary way of calling to account any Minister who errs, or makes an improper charge. There is always the opportunity to challenge his position in the House.

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Unde r Cabinet ,rule, we have to put up with the Minister of Trade and Customs.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Some day, when the honourable member for South Sydney is in the Ministry, he may hear it said that Parliament has to put up with him, and suffer some of his ideas.

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Parliamen t would be putting up with an honest man, anyhow.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: And I am happy to believe that no honourable member is today asked to put up with any one who is dishonest. I do not know that we need pay much attention to those who protest too much. With regard to the amendment, I think that it is a very great mistake indeed for us to lay down the value of any imported article.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: How can pose a proper duty unless we have a value to base it upon?

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member exhausted his eloquence in attempting to prove that a fixed duty was an improper thing. I do not agree with him. I believe in a fixed duty where the range of values is not so great as to lead to enormous differences. The experience of the world in Customs matters is that it is wisest, in the interests of the revenue and of commerce, to impose a fixed duty, if it is at all ticable. Under the present proposal, the duty would be fixed, but in a round-about way which I regard as altogether objectionable. If a fixed duty is imposed the manufacturer or importer will have a fair idea of the terms upon which he is competing. He will know that his competitor cannot get ahead of him by resorting to faked invoices-and such things are not unknown in the commercial world. If the honourable member for Parramatta would ask the importers of Sydney, I am sure that they would tell him that, where the range of values is not too great, they would prefer to have a fixed duty. The honourable and learned member for Bendigo indicates that the protectionist members of the Commission recommended a 25 per cent, ad valorem duty upon the understanding that the basis of value would be Â£ 3 8 or Â£ 4 1 . But the report does not seem to bear that interpretation. It saysi f the duty be raised from 12^ to 25 per cent. ad valorem on the invoice value of stripper harvesters, then an invoice value of ^38 odd will yield a duty of ;Â£io gs. 2d.; that if the present valuation for duty fixed by the Minister of Customs at ^65 be sustained, which now yields a duty of^S 2s. 6d., this at 25 per cent, will give ^16 5s. per machine. There is no indication from the protectionist members of the Commission as to which of these two values should be adopted.

Speaker: Mr MCCOLL
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That was because the matter was in suspense.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not blame the members of' the Commission for that. I understood the honourable and learned member for Bendigo to be speaking with auderate thority on behalf of the other members of the Commission as well as himself, but their report leaves open the quesSydney. tion as to the value upon which the proposed duty of 25 per cent, should be levied. Therefore, we are at liberty we im- assume that they are not unanimous, and do not all agree with the honourable and learned member for Bendigo.

Speaker: Mr HUTCHISON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I know that they are not unanimous.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I question very much if some members of the Commission would agree to the imposition of a duty which would amount, according to the honourable and learned member for Bendigo, to an addition of only Â£ 2 to the amount levied at present. I would ask prac- honourable members who are protectionists to consider the position. The honourable and learned member for Bendigo says that the industry is in danger, and that 'the duty upon the imported article must be materially increased. Then he proposes to increase, the duty from Â£ 8 to Â£ 1 0 . I ask what kind of treatment that is for a protectionist like himself to ladle out to an industry which, upon his own showing, is in danger. For the last twelve months a duty of Â£ 1 0 has been levied.

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No ; the duty levied has been Â£ 8 , and that has been based upon the Minister's arbitrary valuation.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: During the time that the report of the Commission was in course of preparation, and at the time that it was signed, the duty of Â£ 8 was being collected, and yet, while that duty was in existence, the honourable member said that the industry was in danger. Now he is prepared to add only Â£ 2 to the duty. The industry is in danger whilst an Â£& duty is being levied, whereas a duty of Â£ 1 0 will save it. That is the kind of recommendation we get from the honourable and learned member.

Speaker: Mr MCCOLL
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is humbug.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member ought to be a judge of humbug. If the industry is in danger whilst a duty of Â£ 8 is being collected, there is surely necessity for an increase of more than Â£ 2 . I am prepared to vote for a duty of Â£ 1 6 or of any lesser amount, so far as this industry is concerned. Mr HU ME COOK - Hear , hear. That is protection.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is not the moprotection of which the honourable protectionist member has boasted.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That will not suit South

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am willing to take my chance of that. In view of the atto tacks to which this industry has been subjeered from outside the Commonwealth, it is worth our while to render it secure against the unfair competition of manufacturers in other parts of the world. The talk to which we have listened for some time past as to the injury that would be done to the farmer 'by an increase of duties, comes from men who contemplated' with absolute the robbery of our producers by the importers' ring. They never attempted to take any action to safeguard the farmer against the machinations of the importers. I do not see that any injury will be inflicted upon the farmer by an increased duty upon harvesters or agricultural machinery, so long as we take steps to insure that the prices to the consumer are not increased. In this instance we are taking precautions in that direction.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Does the honourable member thirik that Â£ 6 5 is a fair valuation for stripper harvesters?

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I think that it is a fair valuation for machines that have been sold until recently for Â£ 8 1 .

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: U p to Â£ 9 0 .

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That was a little time ago.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The report of the Tariff Commission shows that they have been sold for Â£ 6 3 .

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If that be so, it indicates the length to which competitors from America will go in their endeavour to crush the Australian industry.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It was Martin and Company's machines that were sold for that price.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not know upon what evidence that statement is made.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: -The member has not read the report.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I have read the report.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is contained in the report.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That does not make it gospel.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It shows that the honourable member does not know what he is talking about.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member mav be a Pooh-Bah or the Lord High Executioner, but the fact that a statement is contained in a report does not make it accurate.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is embodied in the evidence given before the

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: d have heard wiser men than the honourable member doubt the accuracy of evidence.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member does not know what he is talking about.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If it wil l satisfy the honourable member, I am prepared to admit equanimity it.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Then the honourable member should sit down, and let somebodv else talk.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I must ask the Committee to assist me in preserving order. If honourable members will insist upon continually interrupting the honourable member who is addressing the Chair, it is impossible to maintain order. - Mr WATSON - In my view, the farming community need apprehend no danger from the imposition of a duty of Â£ 1 0 , Â£*5> JC Â°> 2 o r Â£ 5 upon stripper-harves2 ters, so long as steps are taken to insure that the locally-manufactured machines arÂ« sold at a reasonable price.

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That condition is not embodied in the resolution.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: But it will be embodied in the Bill, and if it were not, I would not be prepared to support as high a duty as I otherwise would.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I stated when I introduced the resolution that it would be embodied in the Bill .

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Exactly . I am quite prepared to admit that it is not wise to impose a duty the operation of which will create a local monopoly unless we take steps to regulate that monopoly, and, if necessary, to dispossess its holders in the interests of the consumer. Here it is proposed to take steps, not only to insure that honourable the wage earners in the industry shall be protected. but that the consumers shall be safeguarded against any possibility of robbery at the hands of either a local or an outside trust. I understand that the duty which it is proposed to levy upon stripper harvesters will be withdrawn if within fifteen months the price of those machines be not reduced to Â£ 6 5 .

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member and those who are with him in this matter should hold a meeting to decide as to which is the correct price.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member must recollect that it is a quarter to 5 'Commission. o'clock in the morning.

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: But we require to know what we are voting upon.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The price of the machines' must be reduced to Â£ 6 5 within fifteen months, or the duty will be withdrawn. With that safeguard it seems to me that no danger need be apprehended by the farmers. In conclusion, I trust that the Committee will hesitate before committing itself to the very round-about method of converting a fixed duty into an ad valorem rate.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I have already told the honourable member that we can solve that difficulty very quickly. Let the Court fix the value of the machines for Customs purposes.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Is it not simpler to say that the duty shall be so much per machine? Let us vote either for or against that proposal, and then the traders will know exactly where they are in reference to the importation of these harvesters. seems to me highly desirable that, above all High Court? things, we should have clearness, and that can best be secured by the imposition of a fixed duty.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Corinella) [4.46] - As between the imposition of a fixed duty and the round-about method proposed by the honourable member for Parramatta, I have no hesitation in endorsing the view of the honourable member for Bland. I hold that an ad valorem duty based upon afixedvalue would simply pre-judge the very question that the imposition of an ad valorem duty is supposed to leave open. I am aware that objections can be urged against ad valorem duties which cannot be urged against fixed duties, but, as I remarked some hours, ago, our difficulty is that we do not know what is the real dutiable value of these machines, and consequently we are unable to say what the specific duty should be. All! parties were agreed last evening that a specific duty based upon the principle of a 25 per cent, ad valorem rate should be imposed. t Mr MCWILLIAMS - How ?

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: All who were in favour of increasing the duty were agreed upon that point. The Minister of Trade and Customs himself said that the Government proposal was based upon the imposition of a 25 per cent, ad valorem rate upon what they regarded as the proper valuation of these machines. I urged that because we did not know what was their fair dutiable value we were not able to translate the inconvenient ad valorem rate into the convenient fixed rate. While the honourable member for Bland was speaking upon the amendment proposed by the deputy leader of the Opposition, the Attorney-General interjected that the Courts were at present engaged in investigating the question of what is the proper dutiable value of these machines-that a Commission has been issued by the Supreme Court to ascertain that value. I wish to know whether it is a fact that an appeal against that Commission is now pending?

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No . There was an appeal to the Full Court from the decision of a single Justice.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Has that appeal been dealt with? " .

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Yes .

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Has it been allowed?

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No .

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Do the Government inIt tend to appeal from that decision to the

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Not from that decision.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Then the Commission is going to Canada to investigate the actual dutiable value of these machines?

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is going somewhere.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: We cannot say what the evidence taken upon commission will show to be the true dutiable value of the machines. I say frankly that I do not believe that the Commission will say that Â£ 6 5 is a fair valuation. I do believe that it will say that something between Â£ 3 8 and Â£ 4 8 is fair. But we are not in a position to decide. If we establish a fixed duty, we are guessing at the value-the very thing that this Commission is going abroad 0 determine. Wliat I want to know from the Minister is this: When that Commission comes back from Canada or the United States, it may be that the case will not turn upon that point after all. I wish to know, whether the case turns upon the evidence obtained by that Commission or not, does the Government intend to accept the results ascertained by the Commission? Assuming that it has the power to fix the value at what it likes, does the Government intend to accept that finding as evidence of the dutiable value of the article?

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No Government would bind itself to accept the finding of any legal Commission.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If the Commission finds, and the Court even finds, that the dutiable value is;, we will say, Â£44, but if the Court also finds that the Government has a right to fix it at Â£ 6 5 , does the Government reserve to itself the right to retain the value at Â£ 6 5 ? I think that that is a fair question, and that the courtesy of an answer is due to me.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It would be positively dishonest on the part of anv Government to do that.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: My vote upon this matter may turn upon that question, and therefore I am entitled to. ask the Minister for information. If the Prime Minister thinks that I am asking anything that is unfair I will stop at once.

Speaker: Mr DEAKI N
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Ballarat-Minister of External Affairs) [4.53]--The Commission, as the honourable member knows, can have no definite result. It will simply take evidence. That evidence may or may. not be conclusive. In this matter there will probably be a margin of difference That margin may be unimportant, or it may be grave and serious. No Government - indeed , I would say no sensible man - to be bound, by his words hereafter would pledge himself in advance to accept the findings of such a Commission. The Government will exercise the same independent judgment as any man would exercise on such a question. The evidence will be before the public, and it will be before the representatives of the public in this House. They will have an opportunity of judging the Government, who will do what, under their responsibility, they believe to be in the public interest.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Corinella) [4.54] - That is not the information which I desired to obtain. I will explain my point again. The Postmaster-General may laugh, but I can assure him that I am earnest in wishing to find out the exact position, and that I shall give nw vote accordingly. What I wish to get at is this: What I understand from the Prime IMinister is that the Government reserves to itself the right-as suming that it has the legal power to do so if the matter in question is decided in its favour-to maintain the valuation at Â£ 6 5, even although the evidence taken on commission shows that Â£ 6 5 is too high. Of course, there may be conflicting views. But suppose that the evidence shows conclusively that the valuation is between Â£ 4 5 and to take a specific case. If the reasonable conclusion from, evidence is that the value is below Â£ 6 5 , does the Government mean that it reserves to itself the right still to keep the valuation at a figure which the evidence does not justify, or does the Government mean that if the evidence enables it to come to a reasonable conclusion, it will accept that conclusion? Does the Government intend bona fide to follow the evidence if the evidence is clear enough to be followed ?

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Is the honourable member referring to the future and to the past, or to the future only, and not to the past?

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: What will happen when the evidence on Commission becomes known ?

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Does the honourable member mean the effect on the case, or on the future duty ?

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: On the future duty, of course. Mr DEAKI N {Ballarat-Minister of External Affairs) [4-57]--As I have said - and it is not a quibble-it is a question of margin. The duty has been fixed on a valuation of Â£ 6 5 . If it is shown by the evidence that the valuation for duly should be between JPfio and Â£ 6 5 , we might retain the valuation at Â£ 6 5 . Under the Act, as I read it. the Government would be entitled to take that view if it considered that the valuation of Â£ 5 5 was artificial, and not the real value. The intention of the Act is that the duty shall lie imposed upon the real value of an article. It is intended to guard against the tricks of trade. The Government will have to take full responsibility for the exercise of its powers in this regard. If there should be any departure from what ought to be done the House will deal with it.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Corinella) [4.58] - The position put by the Government is that, assuming that the evidence enables the Government to form a reasonable conclusion on facts as to what the real value iswhether it is Â£ 6 5 or Â£ 4 0 , or anything between-the Government will deal with it accordingly.

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Certainly ; any Government must.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I say, on the face of that, that if the value as ascertained is to be taken; as the basis, then, assuming that there is a legal power to exercise the authority, I am satisfied to accept the 25 per cent, basis.

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am not.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Of course the honourable member's fiscal views and mine are not in accord. But it is because the matter is in a state of flux that I shrink from fixing the duty now. I think that the 25 per cent, basis is, on the whole, a liberal basis. It is a fair basis under the special circumstances of this case. I do not want to see the duty fixed at Â£ 1 0 if the real value is more than Â£ 4 0 , and I do not want to see tlv duty fixed at Â£ 1 6 if the real value is between Â£ 4 4 and Â£ 6 5 . The 25 per cent, duty might be imposed on the definite understanding that the dutiable value is to be honestly fixed in accordance with the evidence. It is because we do not know what the fixed duty ought to be, and because we really always ascertain it by some reference to the dutiable value that I shrink from a fixed duty now; and I was hoping that the Government would tide us over this coming season at any rate.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: In what way?

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: By imposing an ad valorem duty.

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: We might take the ad valorem duty at the present valuation.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I say this frankly, that there is no evidence to justify a valuation Â°t -Â£ 5 6 I 1 0 w - As I have put my views frankly against those of the importers I want frankly to put the view on the other side. I think that the weight of evidence is against the Â£ 6 5 valuation. That is a limit that no one expects that we shall reach by means of evidence. I did expect that the Government would refix the value. I have looked through the Commission's report and the evidence. That evidence comes largely from a quarter which is interested. evidence which is largely unchecked, because there is no opportunitv of checking it.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The manufacturing price of the Australian machines can be ascertained, and the importers say that theirs can be made more cheaply.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The evidence as to the cost of production here is very vague, although it points in the direction of a value a little under Â£ 4 0 in each case. But I do not think it is conclusive, and, therefore, I do not wish to be bound by it.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Shoul d not the Committee have a reasonable idea from the manufacturers as to the cost of building a harvester ?

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: In my opinion, the silence of the manufacturers or of the importers would entitle us to draw the inference against them.

Speaker: Mr MAUGER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The information was tendered confidentially to the Tariff Commission, and they got it.

Speaker: Mr MCCAV
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The publication of the information to the whole world could not have hurt the business of the manufacturers, so far as the rivalry was concerned.

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Yes , it could.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is impossible to suggest a reason why either importers or local manufacturers could have suffered by disclosing the cost of production, so far as the rivalry between two sets of makers was concerned.

Speaker: Mr MAUGER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The information was given to the Commission, and put in.

Speaker: Mr FULLER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It was never handed into the Commission.

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It was offered.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I defy any one to point to a single reason in this case why either importers or manufacturers could have been hurt by stating the cost of production.

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: A man does not give the secrets of his business away to his rivals.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: In this case the only thing which could have been given away was the amount of profit, because the manufacturers had given away nearly everything except the cost of production.

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Why was not the offer accepted?

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Surely at this hour the honourable member does not want me to go into a matter of that kind ! In my opinion the Government should say to the Committee that while they think that Â£ 3 8 is too It is low a value, they consider that 1^65 is too high, and do not propose to retain the proposed duty of 25 per cent, on the latter basis. For the present an intermediate amount should be fixed upon, and then the tiue value: could be fixed when we had final information to guide us to a determination.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hume-Minister of Trade and Customs) [5.4] - I have listened very carefully to-night to all the speeches, and marvelled that honourable members should have forgotten the statement. I made about a year ago, when this matter was before the House, I forget under what conditions.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: On a motion for the adjournment of the House.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: In my speech, which may be seen in Hansard, I clearly stated the course of action, and why it was taken. When honourable members state that I have not given any information, they ignore what took place on that occasion if on no other.

Speaker: Mr MCWILLIAMS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Was that in reference to the letter from Italv?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not remember whether the document was among the papers on that occasion, but probably it was. When I learned that it was a copy, I compelled the production of the original letter; but that was only one factor in the matter. I am very much surprised indeed at the action taken by the honourable and learned member for Bendigo. I think it will tend very much to influence the hearing of the cases which are now before the Court. If he will only look at the evidence taken by the Tariff Commission, he will find that a valuation of Â£ 5 9 or Â£ 6 0 was given. Honourable members seem to forget that, under the' Customs Act, the Minister has to consider, not only the cost of making a harvester, but all incidental cost until it is placed on board. That is where the whole trouble commences.

Speaker: Mr TOHNSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The f.o.b. value is Â£ 3 8 .

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The f.o.b. value was the value after deducting all expenses from the factory to the ship. What was carried on? I found out that there was a certain value given Â»for the harvesters, 'and that the railway company, and every one connected with the business, were all receiving a part of the rebates. To prevent a continuance of that practice, I did what I was authorized by law to do. I added the full cost of railway freight, commission, and everything up to the point of the article being free on board.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Ye t the local manufacturers of harvesters say that there is no protection against outside competition.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is a matter which is arguable. I am not dealing now with that point, but with the question as to how the value was raised according to law. Section 154 of the Customs Act says thatThe value shall be taken to value of the goods in the principal markets of the country whence the same were exported in the usual and ordinary acceptation of the term, and free on board at the port of export in such country, and a further addition of 10 per cent, on such market value. If the honourable and learned member for Bendigo will look at the statements made to the Commission he will find that they vary. According to the evidence of Mr. Patterson, the cost of making a harvester here is Â£ 4 1 ; the importing expenses and duty amount to Â£ 2 0 ; the setting up costs Â£ 2 ; and then comes in the question of the selling expenses which I have not taken into consideration at all. I have seen some invoices in reference to the freight.  to say that he charges the Â£20?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No . I notice that in one instance the freight was stated at Â£ l , but I have seen invoices where it was given at Â£ 5 . The only thing which has to be taken off the Â£ 2 0 is the freight and duty. If we deduct Â£ 5 for the fieight from the Â£ 2 0 , it leaves Â£ 1 5 . Then if we take the cost of production at Â£ 4 1 , it brings the total cost up to Â£ 5 6 .

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: But the duty has to come off too.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: When I - dealt with the question of value, the duty was about Â£ 4 . If we take the freight at Â£ 5 , and the duty at Â£ 4 , it makes Â£ 9 , and, deducting that from the Â£ 2 0 it leaves Â£ 1 1 . I do not know exactly the cost of setting up a harvester here. I have not been able to go through' the details in the papers, because they have only just been obtained from the Crown Law Offices. If to the Â£ 4 1 we add Â£ 1 1 and 10 per cent', on the market value abroad, it brings the total value to about Â£ 5 9 .

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No; to about Â£56.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I made a calculation here, and, roughly, that is how the value works out. There are some other figures to be included.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Those given by the Minister only total Â£53.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am taking the cost of producing the locally-made machine-Â£4 1 - I think that we ought to take that, and assume that the cost of the imported is_as much as that of the Australian machine.

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is disputed.

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Everythin g is disputed.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The extra Â£3 brings up be the fair market the total to Â£56.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The . Prime Minister is quite right. I am'showing honourable members that according to the figures which the Chairman of the Tariff Commission Has cast aside

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No .

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable and learned member, in connection with this matter, is taking the side of the importers.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is not a fair stateposes. ment. Mr. DEAKIN - He is taking the figures of the importers. Sir. WILLIAM LYNE - Exactly . What I intended "to convey was that the honorlittle able and learned member for Bendigo is accepting the importers' figures in preferwhat ence to those of others. I am told that  than are any others. That being so, if than an ad valorem one. the amendment submitted by the honormuch able and learned member for Bendigo adopted, it will mean that the duty will be based on a valuation of Â£ 1 2 or Â£ 1 less than the evidence contained in the port of the Commission shows should be fixed.

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: How does the honorInternational able gentleman arrive at that conclusion?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: And valorem its duty of 25 per cent., based on a valuation of Â£ 3 8 , is equal 'to a fixed duty of about

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: And the addition 10 per cent, under the Customs Act would bring up the total to Â£41.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I cannot make elaborate calculations at this stage. May were sent > I briefly explain the considerations by which I was influenced in fixing a valuamunication tion of Â£ 6 5 on the imported machines? communicated with the British Consul America, and also sought information in Canada with respect to the cost of these machines, and I received from the Canato dian Government a reply that the Minister had decided not to afford any information regarding the values and manufacture of machinery of this kind intended for exsays, port. Surely honourable members will give me credit for the belief that that was not a very wise attitude to take up. It placed the Customs Department of the Commonbeyond wealth in an extremely difficult position. I wish honourable members to clearlv underthink stand that if the Government can be vinced that the f.o.b. cost is not Â£ 6 5 will be prepared to accept what is an returned. equitable valuation. They certainly have no desire to assess duty on what is more than the true value. But when I found that every manoeuvre was being resorted to-and I dare sav the same thing is done in nearlv all cases-to secure a very invoice for the Customs valuation, it was mv duty to endeavour to ascertain what that view. was the true valuation for Customs purI think! that honourable members will recognise that the duty proposed by the honourable and learned member for Bendigo is altogether too low. I do not say that a valuation of Â£ 6 5 may not be a too high. When I am convinced that it is, I shall be quite prepared to accept is equitable. I had great difficulty in dealing with this matter, and recommend the Committee impose a specific duty rather There is difficulty in ascertaining the be value of machinery, and particularly of these machines, whilst trouble is also ex3 perienced in connection with the importation reof parts. Some of these machines come out in a half-finished state, and parts are introduced in all sorts of conditions. The Harvester Company, which has a factory in Canada, wished to send machines to the other side of America, and knew that if they sent them from a Montreal' they could get them carried at a low rate. A short time ago I received an intimation from the British Consul at of Chicago that when a certain train arrived in that city from Montreal the trucks were opened and Chicago machines were placed in them. Some oif them - to New Zealand, and others to Brisbane, but before "the comfrom the British Consul arrived I they had been distributed, and nothing in could be done. I am not wedded to a duty of Â£ 1 6 ; but it is very hard to determine what is the exact duty that ought be levied. I would ask honourable members what other course is open to us than to fix the ad valorem rate on the valuation we have made. If , as the Prime Minister the report of the Commission which has been issued to take evidence abroad, showed that the valuation was too high, no Minister or Ministry would attempt to go what was clearly proved to be the legitimate assessment. It may be that Â£ 6 5 is not the exact value, but I defy any human being on the slim, or rather difficult, evidence I had, to fix the exact value.

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: " Slim" is a good word.

However, I have now tried to give honourable members all the information I can, and, in addition to that arready given, it ought to satisfy them that I did my best to get at the true value.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Parramatta) [5.24] - The Minister has been very frank with the Committee, and, personally, I am much obliged to him for it. He admits that the present valuation of Â£ 6 5 is too high.

Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I say that it may be. I think that it is a little too high.

Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not wish" to hold the honourable crentleman to exact words. What I wished to know was the state of his mind in regard to this valuation. He tells us that it has undergone some modification.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I wish that the honourable member had to make the valuation, and that I could avoid the trouble of doing so.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I have no quarrel with the Minister on the present occasion. My desire is to get at the facts. We are now considering a proposal for the imposition of a duty, and must have some basis of value in our minds. Is the proposed 25 per cent, ad valorem to be imposed on a valuation of 'Â£65, on a valuation of Â£ 4 5 , or on a valuation of Â£ 3 5 ? - Honourable members may quibble as they like in regard to fixed rates, but every duty when imposed must be at a fixed rate.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Why not move to make the duty Â£ 1 2 ?

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am not prepared to do that. Considering the cost of importing, a duty of Â£ 1 2 would be extortionate, and I should be no party to the imposition of such a rate. We cannot get from the Government a clear statement of their intentions in the-future. All they say now is, " If it is clearly shown that the valuation is too high, it will be lowered." How is it to be clearly shown if the Tariff Commission have been unable to clearly show it? It is true that a Commission has been sent to Canada to investigate the matter; but the Minister has told us that they cannot find the values there, because they are not kept. Surely the Commission which has just been issued will meet with the same difficulties as the Tariff Commission met with.

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: But it will have the great advantage of being on the spot. a

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: There is one thing that we can do, and that is to ascertain the values of the Australian machines.  this duty until they show their hand.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Neve r in my parliamentary career have I known a Commission to be appointed to investigate a subject, and then, without a tittle of justification, to be flouted by Ministers, who insist upon an arbitrary value of their own. No parliamentary Government in existence has ever gone through an experience such as that now proposed. - Mr FISHER - What is the value of the Commission's report? They know nothing about the cost of the machines.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I believe that they know all that is to be known, and that that information is contained in their report. I do not think that any better evidence could be obtained by going to Canada 1,000 times. I am, therefore, prepared to rely upon the Commission's report. They say that the manufacturers of stripper-harvesters in Australia declined to give information respecting the factory cost of making those machines in this country. There is only one course for the Government to take, and that is to decline to alter the duty until the cost of these machines is made known. Mr JOHNSON. :- That would be the straightforward course to take.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: There is no other course to be taken.

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Any excuse for no duty !

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Any excuse and subterfuge for a duty. Men appear before the Tariff Commission, and sav that their industry is prospering, their output increasing by leaps and bounds, and their export trade growing; but they will not tell the Commission anything else. On that information the Government propose to nearly double the existing duty. Here is what the Commission saysfrom the data submitted to the Commission by such manufacturers, viz. Although the manufacturers would not themselves submit the cost, they gave the the cost? Commission the data so that the members could themselves make up the cost - Where sity to socialize this industry. is the difference ? The report proceedsThat the cost of the material of a stripper-hartified vester amounts to about Â£26, and as the wages paid in its manufacture amounts to 30 per cent, of the cost of the finished article, the inference has been drawn that the total cost of a locallytrenched. made stripper-harvester is about Â£37 3s. Assuming this statement and the inference therefrom as being correct, and adding to the cost of materials and the cost of wages per cent, to represent general expenses of manufacturing, management, lighting, insurance, & c , the cost of a complete machine in Australia should work out at about ^ 4 1 . That is the cost of the machine in AusThe tralia

text: But the CommisParty, sion reports that the American machines can be made more cheaply.

I am reading that, although it is against me; I think we ought to have all the facts on which the Commission arrived at a deAfter cision.

The honourable members' franker colleague to-night has said that the industry ought to be socialized as quickly as possible. position of the honourable member for Wide Bay, and of the leader of the Labour is that because this industry cannot be socialized at once, therefore private enterprises should be bolstered up still furand enabled to dip into the pockets of the farmers. I prefer to act all through on the basis of the accuracy of the report the of the Roval Commission, which has investigated the facts so far as the facts are susceptible of investigation, and has presented its conclusions to us. We are told the that from data supplied by manufacturers in Australia, the cost of manufacturing this machine here is not more than Â£ 4 1 , and the cost of manufacture in Canada is a great less than the cost in Australia. Those being the facts, what has the Minister of Trade and Customs to say in reply ? The Minister, first of all, franklv admitted that he regards his present valuation as too high. all the honourable gentleman's ternbast and boasting, he now tells us that his is unfair and unjust-that is the statement from his lips to-night.

Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Minister did not would say anything of the kind. Mr.'JOSEPH COOK - But the Mingave me justification for saying it memfor him. However, there is no use in about the verbiage, because it is clear that the Minister believes the valuation of Â£ 6 5 is too high. In the absence of any data outside that supplied by Royal Commission, on which to form a reliable judgment, what ought we as reasonable men to do? Ought we not to they follow the Royal Commission so far as facts are concerned. It must be remembered that both sections of the Royal Commission signed this report as to the accuracy of the information-free-trader s agreed with protectionists that the valuation was a correct one. We are told by the Minister) that we cannot get any correct information on the point from Canada, and yet, in the meantime, we are to fix a duty. Will the Minister wait until the facts are ascertained before the duty is fixed? The Government will" not even agree to accept the facts when ascertained, and bind themselves to make the duty accordingly. What a farce it is our fixing a duty under the circumstances! to say that I am prepared to withdraw the amendment. I see the difficulty, but I shall not withdraw the amendment unless I am permitted to take the usual course, and move a still lower duty.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Parramatta) ^5.40] - I move That after the words " Stripper-harvesters, - each Â£ 1 6 , " the words " and on and after 7th September, 15 per cent, ad valorem" be inserted. My idea is to adopt the valuation fixed by the Minister, which will evidently remain : in force for some considerable time. At the present rate of progress at least two years must elapse before a legal decision is given in regard to the harvester case. A 15 per cent, duty upon a harvester valued at Â£ 6 5 - would represent an impost of about Â£ 9 15s.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Canobolas) [5.42] - I "wish to refer to one remark made by the honourable member for Bland in the course - of his impassioned address, which appeared to me to be particularly diTected towards myself. The honourable member said that those who were -.objecting to the imposition of increased duties upon stripper - harvesters were prepared to allow the farmers to be handed over to the tender mercies of monopolists. I wish to know whether the honourable member has any faith in the Australian Industries Preservation Bill, which was intended to protect us against the operations of trusts either within or beyond the Commonwealth. He represented to me and to other honourable members that that measure would prove an effective safeguard^ and I accordingly gave it my support. I am as strongly opposed to monopolies of any kind as is the honourable member for Bland, and yet, because I am not prepared to vote for any increased duty upon stripper-harvesters, I am told by the honourable member that I am prepared to play into the hands of monopolists. Has the honourable member come to the conclusion that he made a mistake when he recomI desire mended honourable members to vote for the measure to which I have referred? If so, the sooner he takes us into his confidence and places the position fairly before us the better. I am not disposed to place make-believe enactments on the statute-book. I think that it was most unfair of the honourable member to make the statement he did with respect to myself and others who are opposed to the proposed increased duty. I came into this House under certain pledges to my constituents, and I am going to stand by them as long as I am here, even though I may offend the honourable member for Bland. The question of fixed duties, as compared with ad valorem duties, was fully considered when the Tariff was under discussion, and it was then decided to discard specific and composite duties in favour of ad valorem duties. It was shown that certain fixed duties levied under the Victorian Tariff gave rise to very serious anomalies. In one case the fixed duty upon certain goods resulted'in subjecting the lower-class articles to an impost equivalent to an ad valorem duty of 60 per cent., whilst goods of a higher quality were subject to a duty of only 18 per cent. We have been told that when the strippers were first introduced here the price was fixed at Â£120, whereas the machine could reasonably be sold today for Â£ 4 5 or Â£50. If we fixed the duty for stripper-harvesters upon the basis of a valuation of Â£ 6 5 , we might, within a very short time, find that, owing to improved methods of construction, the machines could be sold for Â£ 2 0 . In such an event, the ad valorem charge would be enormouslv increased. I do not see that any greater difficulty_ would be experienced iÂ»Â» --rmining the value of stripper-harvesters than is met with in fixing the value of a hundred and one of the other articles enumerated in the Tariff. I have no doubt that the protectionist members of the Tariff Commission had a natural inclination to adopt the valuation fixed by the Minister, and I assume that they must have had very good reasons for coming to the conclusion that a lower figure more accurately represented the value. I think that the Minister has made a mistake in fixing the value of the imported stripper-harvester at Â£ 6 5 . If not, it will be unjust to compel the local manufacturers to reduce their price to Â£ 7 0 . The margin between Â£ 6 5 and Â£ 7 0 is not sufficient to yield local manufacturer a reasonable profit. The position presents the two horns of a dilemma. Either Â£ 6 5 is an over valuation, or the proposed decision to arbitrarily fix the selling price within a couple of years at Â£ 7 0 is unwarranted by the facts of the case. I desire to encourage the local manufacture of machinery under reasonable conditions. I would prefer to purchase a machine from an Australian manufacturer than from a foreign manufacturer. But I cannot fail to recognise that whilst the farmers have been sweated by outsiders they have also been imposed upon by our local manufacturers. Consequently, whilst giving; fair consideration to the latter, I do not think that we should place the farming community completely at their mercy. can show quite as good a record from the stand-point of endeavouring to protect the interests of the farmers as can the honourable member for Bland. It comes with ill grace from him to charge me, or those associated with me, of opposing the proposed duty in a covert effort to further the interests of outside manufacturers and monopolists, to the detriment of the class to which I belong.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Wide Bay) [5.52] - As nearly always happens after an all-night sitting, a good deal of feeling has been aroused, and many things have been said which would have been better left unsaid. I have no sympathy whatever with those who make personal charges against individuals occupying high offices. I do not think that such charges ought to be made in a careless way.

Speaker: Mr FISHER

Speaker: Mr FISHER

text: Ver y well. I am content to leave the matter there. It is a singular circumstance that whenever a reference is made to-charges of that character a point of order is raised by the honourable member for Parramatta, who is the deputy leader of the party from which such charges usually emanate.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND

There is one point connected with the report of the Tariff Comission as to which I am exceedingly disappointed. The inquiry conducted by that body has been a pensive one, although the Commission admittedly performed a great work. from all the information supplied to it, the vital facts connected with the manufacture of harvesters have been omitted. desire to know is the actual cost of producing one of these machines in Australia.
