Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is useful information that it costs Â£ 5 2 to manufacture one of machines, but unfortunately it does unnot reach us through the proper channel. If the manufacturers are prepared to swear that statement, why have they not done

Speaker: Mr RONALD
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is in the Tariff Com

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Will the honourable and member show me the place where it can be found? I think that the valuation of Â£ 6 5 , which is the figure fixed by the Minister of Trade and Customs, is too high. After good deal of banter, the Minister has frankly expressed his own opinion that that to valuation is too high. That information I have already said, by way of interjection, that in my opinion it would be dishonest on the am part of a Government after a Commission had been sent to America to ascertain the manufacturing cost of these machines, still to continue to exercise Ministerial power in valuing them at a figure higher than the evidence disclosed to be justified. Minister of Trade and Customs has expressed his opinion upon that point more clearly than did the Prime Minister. He tells us that he is prepared to accept the facts ascertained by the Commission which has gone to America. That is a sensible and straightforward thing to do. Some honourable members have suggested that they would not trust the Minister. I have seen nothing in his conduct to cause me to distrust him in any wav. I would rather trust a Minister who stated straightforwardly that he had taken up a wrong position than I would trust one who was not frank, and w'ho concealed information which he had at his disposal. I do not wish to refer to the differences have arisen between honourable members professing different fiscal faiths.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: What is the honourable member's fiscal faith?

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It is to do the very best I can for the people of Australia. I am free to follow any course that I believe in, and shall not come into conflict with my constituents by doing so.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It was a fair question to ask.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member has taken up one or two different attitudes. I have heard him argue that no duty should be imposed except for revenue purposes. I have also heard him say that, as some people are getting an advantage from certain duties, he does not see why his constituents should not share in those advantages. There are other honourable members who, like the honourable member for New England, say that they would not ask for any assistance throueh the Customs for their constituents. There are some who believe that it would be better for Australia to have no commerce whatever. They believe in absolute prohibition. I cannot share that view by any means. I do say, however, lhat most countries appear to get along in pretty much the same wav. no matter what fiscal principles they adopt. There is, for instance, the great protectionist country of the United States, in which there is some of the bitterest poverty to be found in any country, and as regards the employment of youths and long hours of work in their factories we have nothing to equal the tragedies which take place there. On the other hand, we have boasted free-trade countries in which tens of millions of persons are on the verge of starvation. Believing, as I The do, that the distribution of wealth is unequal and inequitable, can I appear here and vote for the proposal of the Government?

Speaker: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Can the honourable member connect his remarks with the question before the chair ?

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Yes . The question before the Committee is whether a certain import duty would benefit the people. The /TEMPORARY .CHAIRMAN. The question is that on and after the 7 th September there shall be a duty of 15 per cent, on harvesters.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Yes , and the only argument advanced by the Ministry and the lhat Tariff Commission in favour of the proposal is that it would provide work for the people.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member has classified most of us on the fiscal question, but he has not vet classified himself.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am answering the inquiry from the Chair. The imposition of import duties has had various effects in different countries, and in every case the result has been unsatisfactory. I do not think that I ought to trespass on the patience of the Chair to state the reason for the failures. The fiscal policies of various countries have absolutely failed in their object, and that is the better distribution of wealth. I have no reason to think that a prohibitive duty would operate to reduce the price of the harvester, as the Ministry desire, and are passing legislation to insure. I believe that the legislation will more or less fail to achieve that object. I do not think that the Government will be enabled by that means to reduce the price of the harvester to a certain amount. If the manufacturers ignored the law, the Government would not interfere.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member's own proposal would compel them.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I think not, because it does not refer to the selling price.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member suggested the imposition of an Excise duty.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Government state that if the proposed duties be imposed, we are assured that the selling price of the machine will be less than it is at present. But my view is that Parliament ought not to impose high duties without taking care that the employees in the industry shall receive a portion of the benefit so conferred. - Mr CHANTER - That is also to be proposed in the Bill.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: There is no Bill before the Committee. I am doubtful whether the Government will be able to insure that the price of t'he machine shall not be more than a certain sum - and I believe that they honestly desire to attain that object-because there are many methods by which' manufacturers, especially if they have a monopoly, can charge a higher price than that prescribed by the Government. For instance, they could deliver an inferior machine unless we maintained an army of inspectors.

Speaker: Mr STORRER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No one would ruin his business by making an inferior machine,

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I believe that in their own interests the manufacturers would produce the best possible machine, at the same time they would demand the highest price which the farmers would pay. I do not complain on that score. My complaint is that notwithstanding all our investigation and expenditure, we cannot get a definite statement of the sum expended in producing a machine fit for delivery. I have made personal inquiries, and heard that the item of wages does not amount to more than Â£ 1 2 per machine. In my opinion, it would be a fair thing, as proposed, to impose a duty equal to the amount paid in wages in constructing a machine. Like other persons, I had no authority to compel a declaration ofi the true state of affairs. I would not have mentioned the amount if I had not got the information personally, and I believe that, to a certain degree, it is reliable.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Dalley) [6.18] - The honourable member for Canobolas, in defence of his position, described the speech of his leader as an "impassioned address." I put it to the Committee that in two Parliaments we have never heard from a member of the Labour Partv a warmer speech in the early hours of the morning in defence of a proposed duty. There is no doubt that the honourable member for Bland was speaking at high pressure, and that he fought as strenuously for the proposal as if he were Prime Minister. I interjected at the time that he was fighting the principles of the Ministry instead of the principles of the party to which he belonged. The honourable member for Canobolas and the honourable member for Wide Bay, the deputy leader of that party, have practically borne out what I am saying. I think it is wise to put it on record that the honourable member for Bland ,.is such an ardent protectionist that he will put before everything else prohibitive protection as against the protection of labour. The honourable member for Canobolas raked his leader fore and aft when he was absent; but I shall not pursue that course, because I should like to attack him in his presence. I want to emphasize the statement of the honourable member for Wide Bay that the value of the labour in a harvester is Â£ 1 2 , and that because of that .amount of labour the honourable member for Bland and others are asking the Committee to impose a high if not a prohibitive duty. The honourable member for Bland was asked whether he thought that Â£ 6 $ was a fair value, and he said that it was. A little while afterwards the Minister of Trade and Customs said that, in his opinion, it was a little above the value. The honourable member for Parramatta has made a very admirable suggestion, and I think that the difficulty in which we are placed would be overcome very quickly if . it were analyzed. He says that he will press for a duty of 15 per cent, on the Minister's valuation of Â£ 6 5 , which would give an advantage of Â£ g 15s. to the local manufacturers. Two days ago the honourable and learned member for Bendigo asked for a fixed duty of Â£ 1 0 . Although he is an ardent protectionist, still he has receded from that position, and now asks for a duty of 25 per cent., which is equal to a fixed duty of Â£ 1 0 5s. per machine. The free traders were beaten on their proposal to adhere to the agreement for fiscal peace, and thereby retain the existing duty of 12-j per cent., and they now make a very fair proposition. They practically agree to the duty of Â£10 which was asked for by the honourable and learned member for Bendigo, and supported by many protectionists. The members on this side want an ad valorem in preference to a fixed duty, because if the Commission which the Government has appointed should find that a machine is worth less than Â£ 6 5 the consumer would not have to pay on the same value as he would if we had imposed a fixed duty of Â£ 1 0 , or any larger sum.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Are we in every case to appoint a Commission to ascertain the true value of goods for Customs purposes?

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: A Commission has already been appointed. The honourable member apparently is a believer in 40 per cent, duties.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I believe in effective protection. Mr Wilks' - The honourable member for Bland, in the early hours of this morning, said that he believed in a local monopoly as long as the position of the consumer of its products was considered. It is not Iong^ since he supported the passing of a Bill for the repression of monopolies, and the question which the honourable member for Canobolas put as to whether Or not that was a mere make-believe measure was a very pertinent one. If the Australian Industries Preservation Bill is not a mere " make-believe," protectionists should have no reason to fear anything in the shape of dumping. When I rose to address the Committee at 3 o'clock this morning far more Government supporters than members of the Opposition had Spoken to the question.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: When did the honourable member go to sleep?

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It would not do for a free-trader to go to sleep when all these little games are going on. The Government are now fighting for a fixed duty of Â£ 1 6 ; for that is what an ad valorem duty of 25 per cent, on their valuation would amount to. The protectionist members of the Tariff Commission recommended an ad valorem duty of 25 per cent., whereas the free-trade members of it urge that there is no evidence to justify an increase in the Tariff. It seems to me," therefore, that the amendment moved by the honourable member for Parramatta is an admirable compromise. The honourable member for Barker would not have attempted to suggest a duty of Â£12 had" he not believed that the Government would accept it ; and, since his proposal would be equivalent to an ad valorem rate of 18J per cent, on the valuation fixed by the Government, I fail to see why they should fight over what is after all a difference of a couple of pounds. The honourable member for Canobolas is to be highly complimented on the stand he has taken. He has said that he disagrees with the views of his leader on this question, and that he intends to fulfil his pledges to his constituents. I said the other day that I could not fail to notice that there was a cloud on the political horizon, but that I would not take any action in the direction of supporting protectionists' proposals until I had consulted my constituents. When the Tariff was under consideration, I did not vote' for a protectionist duty on machinery that would be of assistance to any of them, and the honourable member for Canobolas is not the only one in this Chamber who is not going back on his election pledges. We are in duty bound to do our best for the electors and for Australia generally. I am not going to be attracted by any proposal to place either the importer or the manufacturer on a pedestal. Both are actuated by the same motives; they are out for "game," and if they can use this Parliament to their advantage they will do so. I have never reflected on a Minister, but regret to say that I have heard serious aspersions cast upon some honourable gentlemen. If an honourable member, no matter on what side of the House he may sit, says a little too much-if he reflects unjustly on the character of a Minister or any other honourable member-h e ought to be prepared to withdraw his statements, because the public character of honourable members ought to be protected; if , on the other hand, he says too little, he should be made to explain himself fully.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Le t us have a division.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: After sitting all nightand the time has been consumed, not by speeches of members of the Opposition, but by those of other honourable membersit is not fair that we should be called upon to commence a new day at half-past 10 o'clock for the transaction of fresh business. I think, therefore, that the Minister should promise that, when he gets this motion through, the Government will consent to adjourn until Tuesday next. We do not wish to be compelled to discuss these proposals till half-past 10, when, under the Standing Orders, no new business can be taken.

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Lang) [6.36] - If I only had my way, there would be no duties on agricultural implements. The evidence laid before the Tariff Commission will convince fair-minded men that the local industry does not need protection, the cost of importing harvesters being in itself suffi cient to secure the local manufacturers from too fierce a competition. If duties had to be imposed, I would prefer ad valorem rates in cases where there were different qualities of the goods affected. But with a Minister like the honourable member for Hume in power, valuations may be so inus creased, on one pretext or another, as has been done in the case of harvesters, that the actual duty imposed by Parliament may be doubled. The Minister admitted this morning that he had no reliable evidence original. upon which to base his harvester valuation, and conveyed the impression that Â£65 was fixed upon to make it certain that there would be no escape for the importer. It is obvious that this is the valuation upon which the proposed increased duty is going to be charged, in entire disregard of the reports of the Tariff Commission. A Commission has been issued by the sufficiently Supreme Court for the purpose of contection ducting an impartial and non-political vestigation as to the values of harvesters in Canada. In the face of all those facts, and in the face of the statement the Minister that it is not possible to get reliable evidence in Canada, we must asenable sume that it is the intention of the vernment to adhere to the value of Â£65. It is not reasonable to trust the administraMinutes tion of ad valorem duties to a Minister the views of the present Minister of Trade and Customs-a Minister who exercises powers of administration in a high-handed, tyrannical, arbitrary, and merciless manner in the persecution of importers. If we could only be sure that the value of article would remain at a certain figure, would not very materially depart from certain figure over a given period, it would be better to have a specific rather than ad valorem duty. We have to-night one bit of entirely new information from the Minister. If the Minister has before him the original papers which were laid on the Library table on the occasion when the adjournment of the House was moved Â£33. for the purpose of discussing this questurers tion, the original letter which was said to pany, have come from Italy is not included. I farmersand went very carefully through all those papers, and all I could find was a copy of a copy of an alleged letter, and all the references in the documents were to the copy of copy. The Minister now informs us that he has since insisted on the production the orirrinal letter, which he has seen, I suppose that that letter is available other persons to see. This is the first time we have been informed that the has seen the original of a document which was the only evidence tendered in support of the application for the increase of Mr Johnson. duties. The Minister has to-night informed that he acted originally on' information contained in the copy of a copy of a letter.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I did not say that; I said that a copy of the letter was first presented, and that I demanded to see the

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: There was then no evidence of the existence of an original, and I should like to ask the Minister if he has any objection to let any other honourable member see the document, which no doubt would be very interesting to every gentleman in the Chamber. I should like to say that the cost of importation is, in itself, high to constitute a natural pro; and in this connection, I direct the inattention of honourable members to the evidence given before the Royal Commission. This natural protection amounts to some of thing like 44 per cent., apart from the duties, and surely that is sufficiently high to any industry to be successfully carGoried on in Australia. I direct honourable members' attention to page 1736 of the of Evidence, Vol. 4, where they of will find the evidence of Mr Alfred Patterson in regard to metals and machinery. his The Minister of Trade and Customs has admitted the evidence of Mr Alfred Patterson to be the most reliable placed before the Commission-a n admission which is in the. dorsed by the whole of the members of _ or the Commission in their recommendations. a The evidence shows that the local manufacturers would derive a sufficiently high an profit without any duty whatever. For had example, the profit derived by the Massey-Harris ComDany is Â£ 8 is. gd. per machine; by the International Harvester Company, Â£ 1 7 gs. $d.; and by the Sunshine Harvester Company, from Â£ 3 1 to Therefore, if the local manufacreduced their price by Â£&, they would knock out the Massey-Harris Comi f they reduced the cost to the by Â£ 1 7 , Ihey would render it impossible for the International Harvester Company to compete with them. A reduction of Â£ 1 7 would bring the price of the a Sunshine harvester down to Â£ 6 4 , which would still yield a profit to the company of equal to 38 per cent. These figures seem and to me to furnish an unanswerable argument for against the imposition of any duty whatever, and to fully justi'fv me in opposing Minister the Government proposal.

Speaker: Mr JOSEFH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Parramatta the [6.55] - I should like to withdraw my amendment, because I think that before attempting tofixanv duty, we should test the feeling of the Committee upon the question as to whether the impost should be a fixed duty, or upon an ad valorem basis. Amendment, by leave, withdrawn. Amendment (by Mr. JOSEPH negativedThat the word " fixed " in the headline, out. Amendment (by Sir LANGDON BONYTHON) proposed - That the following words be added to the item " Stripper-harvesters, Â£16 " :-" and on and after 7th September, 1906, each Â£12."

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Wentworth) [7.3] I hope that the honourable member for Barker will recognise that the Committee were under the impression that they would be afforded an opportunity of voting upon the proposal to levy a duty of Â£ 1 0 upon each of these machines.

Speaker: Mr AUSTIN CHAPMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable, member will have the opportunity of doing that subsequently.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am sure that the honourable member for Barker would be the very last who would desire to achieve a reputation for sharp practice. I trust that he will see that his amendment will place honourable members in a very difficult position.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I should like to point out that when the Tariff was under consideration in 1901-2 no rule was laid down as to whether a higher or a lower duty should first be voted upon by the Committee. The proposals submitted were decided in the order in which they were moved.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Upon a point of order. I should like; to know whether-if the higher duty be carried-honorabl e members will be afforded an opportunity of voting upon a proposal to impose a lower duty?

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If the Committee Carrv the proposal of the honourable member for Barker the ditty of Â£ 1 2 per machine will stand.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: There might be a number of honourable members who wish to record their votes in favour of a lower amount. I am sure that the Ministry have no wish to prevent them doing that.

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: They can move to substitute a lower duty in the amendment.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The rule that the Committee should first vote upon the lower rate of duty proposed is a very good one, and might with advantage be adopted on the present occasion.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: When we were discussing the Tariff, we more than once COOK) decided in favour of a certain duty, and immediately afterwards affirmed that on and after a subsequent date a lower duty be left should be collected. I take it that there is nothing-assumin g that the proposal of the honourable member for Barker be carried-to prevent the Committee from declaring that on and after a subsequent date a duty of Â£ 1 0 per machine shall be imposed upon stripper-harvesters.

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is so.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I would point out to the honourable member for Wide Bay that it is quite competent for any honourable member to move an amendment upon the amendment of the honourable member for Barker to leave out thefigures"12," with a view to insert in lieu thereof the figures " 10." Amendment (by Sir JOHN QUICK) proposed - That the amendment be amended by leaving out the figures " 12" with a view to insert in lieu thereof the figures " 10."

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Corinella) [7.5] - Assum ing that some honourable members are in favour of imposing a duty of Â£ 1 1 upon these machines, the amendment of the honourable and learned member for Bendigo will prevent them from placing that fact upon record. During the discussion of the Tariff, in the first Commonwealth Parliament, the rule was laid down that the Committtee should first vote upon the lowest duty proposed. Divisions were taken upon the amendments submitted in an ascending scale, and thus an opportunity was afforded to honourable members to vote upon each successive amount. The rule which is being adopted in the present instance was not followed upon that occasion,, because it would practically have excluded divisions upon all intermediate rates.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It will be open to any honourable member to move for the insertion of an intermediate rate.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: But in 1901-2 the rule which is at present being followed would have prevented honourable members firom voting upon intermediate rates. I recollect distinctly that time after time honourable members who had proposed a higher rate of duty gave way in order that divisions might be taken upon lower rates. The proposal of the honourable and learned member for Bendigo, if carried, will mean that there will remain only a choice as between a duty of Â£12 and of Â£10.

Speaker: Mr WILKINSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Moreton) [7.8] My recollection of what occurred in 1901-2 differs somewhat from that of the honourable and learned member for Corinella. When the right honourable member for Adelaide submitted the Tariff resolutions, the first proposal put from the Chair always related to the highest rate of duty proposed. The great majority of the duties embodied in the Tariff as it was originally framed were reduced. If we adopted the same practice upon the present occasion, the duty of Â£ 1 6 per machine which has been proposed by the Government would be the first question decided. Mr. JOSEPH COOK .(Parramatta) [7.9] - I confess that I do not see any in- Crouch, R. A. superable difficultv in this matter. I admit that my recollection is that, when the first Tariff was under consideration, we first considered the lowest duty proposed, and then decided the other duties in the order in which they were submitted.

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: As the honourable member for Moreton has pointed out, the duties proposed by the right honourable member for Adelaide were in nearly every instance higherthan those which were agreed to by Parliament.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: However , it seems to me that that does not matter. After honourable members have voted upon the proposal of the honourable member for Barker, it will be quite competent for them to move that on and after a certain date the duty imposed upon harvesters shall be Â£ 1 1 . Therefore, I do not see the slightest difficulty about the matter. I am prepared to adopt the method proposed, seeing that we shall be in precisely the same position as if we adopted the alternament tive method. Question-that the figures "12," proposed to be left out, stand part of the proposed amendment-put . The Committee divided. Ayes 21 Noes 17 Majority AYES. Bonython, Sir J. L . Mauger, S. Carpenter, W. Willis, H . Fuller, G. W. Wilson, J. G. Johnson, W. E. Tellers : Kellv, W. H . Wilks, W. H . Lee,' H . W. MCWilliams, W. PAIRS. Harper, R. Mahon, H . Ronald, J. B. MCLean, A. Groom, L . E. Watkins, D . Fowler, J. M . Storrer, D. Fysh, Sir P. O. Frazer, C. E. Gibb, J. Bamford, F. W. Hughes, W. M . Higgins, H . B. Lonsdale, E. Question so resolved in the affirmative. Amendment of the amendment negatived.  posedThat the amendment be amended by leaving out the figures " 12," with a view to insert in lieu thereof the figures " 11."

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Riverina) [7.18] - I desire to make a personal explanation. I have been 'i'nfornied by the Opposition whip that in the last division I was paired with the honourable member for Hunter. Personally, I did not pair with any honourable member, but I find that the Governwhip paired me, and therefore I accept that pair. I voted without knowing of the arrangement.

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Laanecoorie) [7.19] - I asked the Government whip when I entered the chamber just before the division was taken whether I was paired, and he told me that I was not. He has since informed me that I was paired, but that he had overlooked the fact. I need hardly say that I had not the slightest idea that I was paired, or I should not have voted..

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Bourke) [719] Some explanation is due from me. We have had two or three divisions on this subject. The honourable member for Wentworth has been acting as Opposition whip, and previous to the last division, by arrangement between us, no pairs were recorded - When the last division was about to be held, I looked round the chamber to see whether my pairs had gone out, and I thought that none of those honourable members whom -1 had paired were taking part in the division. Perhaps the fault was mine, but I point out that no difference was made to the result of the division, except that if none of those honourable members who had paired had voted, the majority would have been reduced. I admit that a mistake has occurred, and am very sorry for it.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Werriwa) [7.20] - Surely the Committee will accept the amendment, because it is evident that the amount of proposed duty is more than the amount paid in wages for the construction of a harvesTariff ter. The discussion has shown that the wages are not less in Canada and America than in Australia. Yet it is proposed depart from a sound rule, which, I think, would have commended itself to even prowas tectionists. Mr KING O'MALLEY (Darwin) [7.21]. - I am in favour of imposing a duty of Â£ 1 2 per machine. I am paired with the honourable member for Parkes, but I wish to say that, in my opinion, that duty is enough. When I look round the Chamber I see honourable members who came in here clothed in protectionist doctrines from to toes. It seems to me that a mighty earthquake has shaken their foundation, and that their protectionist principles fallen into a great chasm. Apparently have become so nude of political principles that if it were a personal instead of a tical matter, they would be arrested for decency.

Speaker: Mr FOYNTON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Grey) [7.24] - I wish test Australian manufacturers. to tell the honourable member for who has just woke up, that the duty proposed is nearly equivalent to the of labour in the production of a harvester. We are informed on the best authority it is possible to get that 30 per cent, on value of the finished article total cost of labour employed in its production. The only testimony at our disposal represents a fixed duty of Â£ per machine; so that the honourable member for Darwin is very generous to the manufacturers, who have not had the courage to produce their books or give us any information. They have been eager enough, however, to come down to us and plead for assistance. They want to secure for themselves the Australian market, and yet up to this time they have refused to tell us the cost of production. I look upon it as protection run mad to impose a duty equal to the total cost of the labour employed in the production of a machine. It may suit the honourable member for Darwin, but it will not suit me.

Speaker: Mr STORRER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Bass) [7.26] - At about 2 o'clock this morning I agreed to pair with an honourable member on the understanding that the point at issue would be settled in the course of a few minutes, and that he was to go home. I am in favour of the amendment, and I regret this conthe tinual slating of Australian manufacturers, because it was not at their request that the Commission was appointed. It was represented to the late Government that the people of Australia were suffering through certain manufacturers losing their trade, to and that men were accordingly thrown out of work, and, therefore, the Commission appointed. I am surprised to find that Labour members, who ought to tafke an interest in our working men, prefer money to be sent to Canada or somewhere else than to be given to our own people. I cannot understand why some representatives of worknot ing men should be continually urging that manufacturers should produce their books. If they were in business they would not nose be prepared to produce their books to any Board, and for their cost of production to be published broadcast. I , as a manufachave turer, contend that it is not the province they of Parliament to ask a business man to show his books. I feel certain that impoliporters have never been asked, for instance, into show their invoices to drapers. It seems to me that some honourable members are very fond of importers, but deAt 2 Darwin, o'clock this morning I agreed to now pair under a misapprehension, and I am cost sorry that I did. This morning we have seen two honourable members voting who were paired, six outside paired, while eight the members of the Opposition have been restrepresents the ing in their homes.

Speaker: Mr MCCOLL
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Echuca) [7.28] - Thre e 1 2 8s. hours ago a proposition was made to honourable members on this side that the suggested duty of Â£ 1 2 per machine should be accepted, and a return offer was made that a duty of Â£ 1 1 would be agreed to, being equal to 25 per cent, on the value of the machine, as found by the Tariff Commission. After careful examination, it has been found that the value is a few shillings under Â£ 4 4 , so that a duty of Â£ 1 1 is equivalent to the duty of 25 per cent, recommended by the Commission. The charge that we have no consideration for manufacturers, and favour importers, utterly fails when it is remembered that it is proposed to grant more than double the present duty. I am prepared to follow the lead of the honourable member for Bendigo, and to vote for a duty of Â£ 1 1 , which is equal to an ad valorem duty of 25 per cent.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Wide Bay) [7.29] - To say that the imposition of high duties would make work for the people and bring about an era of prosperity is just about as accurate as to say that in those countries where the highest duties are levied the greatest destitution exists. If we could give to every Australian industry a protection equal to the total cost of the labour employed in producing the article, what would be the result? According to the honourable member for Bass, there must be a great mystery regarding the cost of producing a smali article like a stripper-harvester, and we are asked to respect it. Messrs. Harland and Wolff, however, will show the cost of each item; but, of course, they would have to produce their, books. Miuch has been said as to the refusal of these manufacturers to produce their books.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I say most decidedly that they ought to produce them.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I have always admired the resolute will of the Minister. When he takes a work in hand he can generally carry it through.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I have never been able to obtain the books.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: And the honourable gentleman wishes to ascertain the facts?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Most decidedly.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Fro m the point of view of the honourable member for Bass, there is a good deal of force in the argument that there are many trade secrets, and that one man does not know what it costs another in the same trade to produce a given article. That argument, however, is not a sufficient justification for the attitude taken up by these manufacturers. We ought to know what is the cost of production, because the Wages Boards will want to know what wages the employees are paid. It is an easy matter to keep a record of the time occupied by a man in working on a piece of machinery. The honourable member for Fremantle inquired where the cost of production begins. In my opinion, it starts from the time that the raw material is taken into the factory.

Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: And that is sometimes a finished product.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: What a notable statement! We produce no steel from Australian ore, and, therefore, we must import for use in the manufacture of these machines what is the finished product of another person.

Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member has missed the point.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Some honourable members may be disposed to be hilarious over the prospect of securing a very high duty, and I shall not regret its imposition if it be the verdict of the Committee; but, at the same time, I would point out that if this proposal be carried to its logical conclusion it will not have the effect which some of mv honourable friends imagine.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Canobolas) [7.34]-- I wish to point out that in New South Wales alone there are 74,000 landholders, 66,000 of whom occupy areas under 1,000 acres in extent, and that they cultivate fully half of the land which they hold. Most of the cultivated land is held by small farmers, whose means are limited, and who have, consequently, to work on a narrow margin. It is essential to their success that they shall be able to obtain their machinery at a reasonable price.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: We propose to enable them to get it at a reasonable price.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: This proposal means that we are to give the local manufacturer a protection equivalent to the total cost of the labour and material employed in building the machines.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Some members of the Opposition have said that a duty of Â£ 1 1 will be equivalent to the labour cost, but not to the cost of labour and material.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am informed that the Tariff Commission report that it would be equivalent to both.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No .  to the cost of the labour.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Surely that should be sufficient. As the honourable member for Wide Bay has pointed out, when local manufacturers refuse to produce their books to assist us in estimating the correct valuation to be placed on these machines, they put themselves out of court. I was glad to hear the Minister say that, in his opinion, these books should be produced. If it is possible for an Arbitration Court to secure the production of books in order that necessary information relative to an industry may be obtained, why should we not be able to do the same? From the refusal of the manufacturers to produce their books the inference may fairly be drawn that the proposed duty is not warranted. are only twenty-four manufacturers of agricultural machinery in Australia, as against more than 270,000 farmers, who will be affected by this proposal, and I repeat that if we grant a protection equivalent to the labour cost of these machines we shall give the former substantial assistance.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Werriwa) [7.40] - It is generally urged by protectionists that duties are imposed to cover the difference between the wages in force in the competing and protected' countries. But we are being asked to vote for a duty which will give an advantage to the local manufacturer equal to more than the total sum which he pays in wages. Although the cost of the harvesters has been referred to as about Â£ 3 7 , I know that when one of the chief manufacturers was trying to obtain financial assistance he said that he could produce machines for between Â£ 2 8 and Â£ 2 9 . I informed honourable members of that fact some months ago, and tried to get a member of the Tariff Commission to question Mr MCKay on the subject; but he declined to give any information in regard to cost. The International Harvester Company have stated that their machines do not cost more than Â£ 2 8 each. As the carriage and other charges upon imported machines amount to Â£ 1 4 , and the Committee has rejected the proposal to make the duty jQio, honourable members evidently intend to give the local manufacturers an advantage of at least Â£ 2 5 . Is not that going altogether too far? The Ministry and its supporters are pledged to maintain fiscal peace; but they are so forgetful of their pledges that at the very end of the last session of the Parliament they are bringing forward these controversial proposals. One cannot but feel contempt for [146] their action. The haivesting season is ap proaching, and, as the effect of the proposed duties will be to prohibit importation, there may be a shortage of machines. The promise of the manufacturers not to increase prices is worth noting, because any man could buy up a whole season's output and re-sell at a higher price. Probably the outside local manufacturers are not aware of the agreement between MCKay and the Minister, and have not made arrangements for a supply of timber and other requirements to enable them to meet the increased demand which a stoppage of importation is likely to cause. This, instead of being a deliberative assembly, has become a mere There recording assembly for the registration of agreements made behind our backs. I shall have to vote for the Â£ 1 1 duty, because it is impossible to get the Committee to agree to a lower rate.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Robertson) [7.49] - I enter my protest against what is being done. The proposed duty means prohibition. In the past, these machines have been sold for as little as Â£ 6 3 , and we have it in the evidence that a handsome profit could be obtained by selling them at Â£ 7 0 . As Mr Gladstone said on one occasion, this is not protection-it is imposition and robbery. The users of harvesters are numerous in the. district which I represent, and it is a shameful thing that they should have to pay a duty of jQi 2 on each machine they buy. I hope that the effect will be to bring the Massey-Harris Company and the International Harvester Company into Victoria to compete with those people who want a monopoly of this industry.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I should not object to the Massey-Harris Company.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: O r the International Harvester Company?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not know about that company.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: We may depend that these companies will come into Australia to manufacture, and will smash up the Australian combine.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I smashed that up long ago.

Speaker: Mr HENRY WILLIS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: There is at present a silent combine in the business, because there is no difference in prices. In 1890 in South Australia machines, which required no more labour than those now on the market, were sold at Â£ 7 3 ; and machines can be produced as cheaply now as then. I intend to protest against this extortion, this robbery of the people-whic h does not result in protection. This industry can defy competition, and, therefore, does not need protection; and I think the Prime Minister and others are honest in saying that the object is prohibition. It is a standing disgrace to the Government to propose prohibition, and the establishment of a monopoly, for which the consumer will ultimately have to pay.  apparent, from the apathy shown on this side of the House, that there is a determination to perpetrate this robbery.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Order ; the honourable member must withdraw that remark.  that if we impose the duty now 'The CHAIRMAN - Order ; the honourable member must withdraw the statement he has made.  draw the word "robbery," and say that this is the worse imposition ever perpetrated on the Commonwealth. With the natural protection df Â£ 1 4 16s. 6d., and the proposed duty of Â£ 1 2 , we shall practically give protection amounting to Â£ 2 6 16s. 6d. on a machine which costs Â£ 3 8 . Yet honourable members are content to sit down quietly while a deliberate attempt is made to confer this advantage on a few individuals who have craved, at Parliament House and at public meetings, for an increased duty, but who have not had the manliness to show us what is the cost of their product. So far as I am concerned, this duty shall not be imposed. I should be ashamed to meet my constituents-me n who have had to suffer from drought, and whose wives and families have had to live practically on boiled wheat-if I countenanced such a proposal. In Victoria there is a manufacturer of this class of machine who last year made Â£34,000. Yet honourable members can sit down calmly while this piece of political robbery is going on. So far as I am concerned, if I can get any one to support me, this proposal shall not go through this week. During the whole course of the Tariff debate, a few years ago, there was not a single instance of our having allowed practically the whole cost of labour as the measure of protection. What has the argument been all along with protectionists? They declare that in other parts of the world labour is cheap; and, because of that, they desire to make up the difference between the wages. What is the difference in this particular instance? The difference is practically Â£ 2 9s. 4d.; and, in consideration of that, it is proposed to give protection amounting to Â£ 2 6 16s. 6d., or nearly three-fourths of the value of the whole machine.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: This is a proper labour man 1

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Do those manufacturers not also get a benefit under the Bonus Bill ?  the anti-dumping legislation. To-day we have been told that out of seventy associations of farmers, fiftv have expressed their opposition to the proposed duty. Really, it would appear as if people in Melbourne knew better what farmers required than do the farmers themselves. It is crue'l and criminal to impose this duty in a dying Parliament. Let the Government go to the country, on this issue; and I venture to say that there would be a very different vote to that which we saw a little while ago. I ask the supporters of the proposed duty to go into the country districts and advocate it. 1 venture to say that no farming com-, munity would return a representative pledged to this policy. When people come here craving for the whole of the market of Australia-urgin g that a wall should be erected around the Commonwealth - is it unreasonable to ask them to tell what it costs to make this machine? Yet the Tariff Commission has been treated with absolute contempt by men who can sit all night here waiting in order that this money may be put into their pockets. As I said before, so far as I am concerned, the duty shall not be passed at the proposed rate.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Moira) [8.0] - Mr . Chairman

Speaker: Mr DEAKIN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Her e is a man who uses a machine!

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I must compliment the honourable member for Grey on the wonderful vitality he displays at this hour of the morning after a most arduous sitting. I could quite understand the righteous indignation displayed by the honourable member if any attempt were made to despoil the unfortunate people whom he has depicted in the farming districts of Australia. My heart goes out to them.  ber shows that by proposing to give the manufacturers a protection equal to Â£ 2 6 per machine.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I appreciate to the fullest extent the sympathy which the honourable member displays for the farmers of South Australia, but I join issue with him when he states that certain honourable members, including myself, have no consideration for them. Furthermore, I take exception to his statement that certain honourable members have come here to pander - to Che manufacturers. I entered public life as a protectionist, and I came into this House at the last election pledged to uphold protectionist principles.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The member was also pledged to fiscal peace.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: This fiscal war is not of my seeking. My constituents knowvery well that I shall vote every time for what I conceive to be effective protection. I stated last night how far I was prepared to go. In my opinion, the imposition the increased duty will not have the effect of increasing the price of harvesters, on the other hand, will tend to diminish their cost to the consumers.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Then the honourable member would support the imposition of a duty of Â£ 1 6 per machine?

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I said so last night, and I made a similar statement twelve months ago. When the action of the Minister of Trade and Customs in regard to the re-adjustment of the valuation harvesters was under discussion, I stated that if the valuation had been raised to convictions Â£ 1 0 0 , and a duty much higher than that now proposed by the Government had been collected, the cost of the machines farmer would not have been increased. whom I represent. Results have justified my opinion, inasin much as the increase in the duty by about 100 per cent, did not result in advancing the price of harvesters. With regard to the proposed increase, I think that the entire community. case was very plainly presented by th? honourable member for Bland. The duty that is now being collected amounts to about Â£ 9 per machine, and according to the figures supplied by the representatives the importers themselves, the value of their machines is about Â£ 4 6 or Â£ 4 7 . Thererepresented fore a duty of 25 per cent, would be [ l 6 ] - 2' 4 an equivalent to a fixed impost of Â£ 1 2 . I am prepared to accept that. Apart from anything that may be said in regard to other industries, the imposition of protective duties upon agricultural implements and machinery has tended to reduce rather than to increase the price to the consumer. Within the last fortnight certain protective duties were proposed for the benefit of the man on the land. Upon that occasion the honourable member for Grey, who is now denouncing those who are supporting a duty of 25 per cent, had nothing whatever to say against a proposal to give the vignerons of Australia a much higher degree of protection.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That was partly a moral and partly a fiscal question.  honourable given to the Australian producers of brandy owing to the special value of their product for medicinal purposes.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I wish to direct special; attention to the fact that the honourable member for Grey and others who of are displaying so much righteous indignation with regard to the present proposal but, had no compunction about imposing a still higher rate of duty for the special benefit of their constituents. I am reminded of the statement made by the honourable and learned member for Angas, that it is upon such occasions that a convenient half-wayhouse is provided for those who are free, traders by conviction, but protectionists by strict necessity. Apparently the honourable member for Grey was compelled by strict necessity to vote in favour of giving a of preference to the Australian brandy producers, and was induced by his free-trade to keep silent. I am not prepared to sit quietly by whilst any honourable member accuses me of acting into the such a manner as to impoverish those T have no interest the manufacturers of these machines, but if we establish factories under the conditions which prevail in Australia. I maintain that a benefit will be conferred upon the

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Boothby) [8.12] In reply to the remarks of the honourable of member for Moira, I wish to point out that there are no grapes grown in the district by the honourable member for Grev for commercial purposes. I might further remind the Committee that it is grossly unfair to twit the honourable member with having deserted his free-trade principles in order to serve the interests of his own electorate in connection with the salt duty. Whilst it is true that a large quantity of salt is produced in his constituency it is not produced for commercial purposes. His vote upon the occasion to which reference has been made was cast in the interests of the producers of South Australia. As a protectionist I have always felt grateful to him for the assistance which he rendered us, and it comes with ill-grace from protectionist members of the Committee to gibe at him.  duty upon salt, but simply against a recommittal of the item.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Exactly . In my opinion, the honourable member has been one of the most consistent free-traders the House.  honourable members should forget the tender mercies of the local manufacturers Of stripmonopoly. per-harvesters, I propose to read a few tracts from the report of the Tariff mission.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: This looks like a ter '" stone-wall."

Speaker: Mr FOYNTON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable memterly ber for Riverina is a good judge of " stonemanufacturers walling " tactics. Although I recognise that I am in a minority, I do not think that any harm can accrue from a repetition certain statements

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member will be out of order if he indulges in repetition.  ago the local manufacturers of strippertralian harvesters expressed their sympathy with the farmers in a very practical way by creasing the price of their machines from Â£ 6 3 to Â£ 8 0 . We are assured upon the best possible authority that that charge a gross imposition, and yet it is now posed to allow these manufacturers to should charge Â£ 8 1 for their machines for another twelve months.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No .  posal will not apply to the present time.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Yes , it will.  until 1907. Sir William LYNE - I intend to propose that the price of stripper-harvesters shall not exceed Â£ 7 5 until next February, and that it shall then be reduced to

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: But the machine only costs Â£ 3 8 to produce.  that the cost of these machines shall be reduced by Â£ 6 , although it is well known that the present price is nothing short of an imposition. If they were to lower the price to Â£ 6 5 the manufacturers would still make a very fair profit on the cost of

Speaker: Mr HUTCHISON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: What would the im- porters charge if they had their way ?  about the importers any more than about in the manufacturers;; but I am concerned about the men who have to use these maI would not trust either an importer or a manufacturer if he had a I want to know how the Goexvernment is going to enforce the reduction Comof Â£ 6 , of which we have heard so much? If it were proposed to deal with the matby way of excise on every machine sold, there would be some guarantee; but at present the proposal in that.respect is utunworkable. In October, 1902, these put their heads together and formed a combine, in conjunction with the importers, for the purpose of forcing prices. of They fixed a minimum price of Â£ 8 4 in New South Wales, and Â£ 8 1 in Victoria. Mr MCKay told the Tariff Commission that he considered those prices only fair. What he terms a fair profit is Â£ 1 8 2s. 6d. per machine. After the two South Ausmanufacturers joined the combine the price of machines which had formerly inbeen sold for Â£ 6 3 in the Wimmera District of Victoria was raised to Â£ 8 1 . The guarantee of the local makers is worth absowas lutely nothing. I am astonished that prorepresentatives of farming constituencies agree to such proposals. Not only the House, sulted by these but the country, has been inmen, who can find time to come here night after night, attend meetings all over the city, and subscribe funds sending men to work up an agitation, but who will not tell us the cost of producing a harvester. We have no desire to interfere with their business If they care to run their concerns without an appeal to the House it is quite a matter of indifference to us what the cost of production is. But when it is deliberately proposed to increase the duty in order to secure to them the Australian market, and to shut out other implements of the kind, we have a right to know the cost of production. Let the proposal be hung up until we can ascertain how much more protection it involves than is now disclosed to us. The only way in which it has been possible to get an idea of the approximate cost of producing a harvester has been to ascertain from one party the cost of the material, and get from another party the percentage of the material in the manufactured article. By that means we have been able to elicit that Â£ 3 8 is a fair estimate of the cost price. Suppose that a fixed duty of Â£ 1 2 were imposed, what a silly position a representative of the people would be in when he went on to a platform in his constituency, and was asked by an elector to state the cost of constructing a harvester ! He would have to admit that, although the Parliament had secured the Australian market to the local manufacturers, he could not answer that question. I venture to predict that in the near future there will be an enormous increase in the production of harvesters. We are just approaching the solution of the great question of closer settlement. As the number of settlers increases, so the demand for the harvester will increase, and it will be possible for the manufacturers to penalize the farmers.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Sitting suspended from 8.35 to 0.35 a.m. (Friday).  Minister of Trade and Customs, and those associated with him in this movement do not realise that there is every indication that within the next ten vears the area at present under cultivation will be increased tenfold. In this morning's newspaper reference is made to a proposition to resume some millions of acres, and I am satisfied that within the next few years .many thousands of these machines will be in use. We should do nothing to prevent those going on the land from obtaining the machines at the lowest possible rate.

Speaker: Mr RONALD
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The local supply would be reasonable enough.  factories in Australia will not be equal to the demand for these machines a few years hence. On almost every holding where wheat is raised, one of these harvesters is to be found, and the demand for them must steadily increase as the area under closer settlement expands. The Government propose to place these manufactures in the hands of a few. Is it their intention that the farmers of Australia shall not have an opportunity to secure improved machinery from abroad? It is true that the Australian harvester is an excellent machine, but I venture to assert that the manufacturers here have yet to learn much in respect of machinery that is now being imported. If we adopt the Government proposal, it will be said later on that we should protect makers of all kinds of agricultural implements by proportionately high duties. It is a singular thing that whilst the manufacturer requires his tools of trade - and every piece of machine'ry necessary for his work-to be placed on the free list, he is anxious to have a high Tariff wall to protect his own industry. It is unfair 'for the Government to attempt, on the eve of a general election, to force this proposal through the Parliament. Some honourable members appear to know little of the privations suffered by the backwoods men. I know of districts where men have taken up vermin-infested areas which they have to fence in with wire netting before they can produce a sheaf of hay. Men who have taken up these agricultural holdings are fighting valiantly against heavy odds, and yet it is proposed to place them in the hands of these manufacturers, who, instead of rising to the occasion, show, in some cases, a tendency to build unnecessarily heavy machines. To this cause the extent of the importations of harvesters may be largely ascribed. In some cases the weight of the local machine is so much greater than is that of the imported, that an additional horse is necessary to haul it, and that is an important consideration to a struggling farmer. The Government invite us to, in effect, shut our imports, and thus to do away with the incentive to local manufacturers to keep their machines thoroughly up-to-date. I would make a final appeal to the Minister to accept my proposal. It may be suggested that the difference of Â£ 1 will be of no material importance, but there is no doubt that it will make a great difference to the farmer. There is every reason to suppose that the manufacturers will advance their prices to an extent corresponding with the increase of duty. We know very well that when a duty was imposed upon oatmeal the price of that commodity was advanced to the fullest limit of the protection granted to the local manufacturersSo it is in every other case. We have evidence that the manufacturers of harvesters deliberately entered into a conspiracy to increase the price of their machines from Â£ 6 3 to Â£ 8 1 , and have for some years past been deriving the benefit of this advance. To my mind we should be legalizing robbery if we afforded them any further facilities for imposing upon farmers, many of whom have been struggling for years against adverse conditions. Surely a duty of Â£ 1 0 per machine should be sufficient to give the manufacturers all the necessary protection they need. should, in effect, be sufficient to recoup fhem for the whole of the labour expended. If that is not protection run mad I do not know anything about the subject.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Werriwa) [9.50] - I cordially endorse the remarks of the honourable member for Grey, and I was very pleased to listen to his contribution to the debate. According to the proposal now before us, the farmers of Australia are to be called upon to pay the whole of the wages of the men employed in the manufacture of harvesters, whilst their employers are to be permitted to pocket the profits. We have been assured that the manufacturers will be required to sell their machines at a smaller price than they would be able to obtain if they were free from alt restrictions. Further, it is started that provision will be made for an immediate reduction of the price to Â£ 7 5 ; but I would point out that two years ago, before the methods of production were improved, harvesters were being sold for Â£ 6 5 . Thus the reduction offered is worth absolutely nothing, and is intended merely to deceive the farmers. According to the evidence given before the Tariff Commission, the local manufacturers entered into a combination in October, 1904, and raised their prices to Â£ 8 1 . They were previously selling their machines at Â£ 7 0 , and at a 10 per cent, reduction on that price in the case of purchases made direct from the manufacturers. As a matter of fact, the Murtoa Farmers' Union had machines offered to them at Â£ 6 2 each. If it had not been for the combination among the manufacturers, 1ihe stiripper-harvesters would have been available to the farmers at a price much lower than that proposed to be fixed under the Bill which the Minister has promised to introduce. It is perfectly plain that the action now proposed to be taken will have the effect of keeping up prices, instead of exerting an influence in the opposite direction. There will be no competition from outside, and the local manufacturers' ring will be able to work their own sweet will upon the farmers, who are being deceived and tricked in every possible way. I thank the honourable member for Grey for his speech; and I can say that I fully endorse the opinions he expressed.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: New England) [9.55]. - This attempt to raise the duty on harvesters is simply an outrage, especially in , It view of the fact that our manufacturers are already selling these machines at a very great profit. We know that some time ago the price was as low as Â£ 6 0 , and that it was raised to Â£ 8 1 , owing to the action of the ring. I refuse to be a party to helping any combination of the kind. I cannot tforget that St was becaujse of the action of the inside men that the ring was brought into existence. The Australian manufacturers could get the whole of the trade by selling their machines at a fair price; but this they have refused to do. One of the importing firms is now selling this machine at Â£ 7 0 , and we ought not to consent to the proposal before us simply in order to give the Minister an opportunity to say that owing to the imposition of the new duty the price has been reduced. In my opinion, at least Â£26 worth of the material in each machine is imported, leaving only Â£ 1 3 worth of labour to be done within Australia.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If there are duties on the parts imported, it gives the local .manufacturer a strong case for a duty on the finished article.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: There may be a duty on the smaller parts, although there is no duty on iron and steel; but that is not the point. I desire to emphasize the fact that a duty of Â£ 1 6 per machine is proposed in order that Â£ 1 3 worth of work may be created within the Commonwealth.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The duty will be reduced to Â£ 1 2 .

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: But jthe "Minister, proposed that it should be Â£ 1 6 That harvesters can be made here successfully is proved by the immense increase of the local output of late years. Last year the local production largely exceeded the importation. The proposed increase of duty will not benefit the consumers, because it will not reduce prices. On the contrary, it will give the manufacturers an opportunity to charge more for their machines. It is claimed that it will give more employwealth. ment to our people; but while if all the agricultural implements required in Australia are manufactured locally, employment may be found in the industry for perhaps 600 men more than are now engaged in it, work will be taken from the large number now connected with the business of importing. The coming here of ships gives work to our people in many directions, and 'the stoppage of importation would injure them by putting an end to their employment. It is, however, well known that it is impossible to manufacture locally all the agricultural implements and machinery required by Australian farmers and cultivators. Between 1900 and 1904 the value of the output of the Victorian implement industry increased by Â£199,000, and the number of Hands employed by 350, so that 600 is a very liberal estimate of the number to whom employment would be given if the whole agricultural implement trade was under the control of the local manufacturers. At the present time there are 2.770 people connected with the industry.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Is the honourable member sure of his figures? Mr. LONSDALE - Yes . They have been taken from the Tariff Commission's report. In Victoria the number of hands employed in the industry in 1899 was 1,107, and in 1905, 1,624; in South Australia in 1899, 242, and in 1905, 723; in New South Wales in 1899, 193, and in 1905, 386; and in Western Australia in 1899, 38, and in 1905, 39. There are no figures available for Queensland and Tasmania. Thus it will be seen that the total number employed in the Commonwealth in 1905 was only 2,770. Adding to that number the 600 to whom work might be given if the whole of. the agricultural implement making were done in Australia-whic h is an over-estimate-the total number then employed would be only 3,370. To get the 7,13 worth of work done in making a harvester the people of Australia are asked to pay a duty of Â£16. No doubt these remarks are displeasing to those who are helping the manufacturers tofleecethe public, but that will not prevent me from proclaiming my views on the subject. The Treasurer, speaking yesterday at a luncheon, said that last year Australia's exports were valued at Â£54,000,000, of which Â£38,000,000 represented the produce from farming and grazing, while Â£16,000,000 was mineral Yet, for the sake of the miserable industry of harvester making, which has proved that it can do well without a duty, it is proposed to penalize our producers in every direction. I shall vote to secure whatever reduction of the proposed duty can be obtained. Question-That the words proposed to be inserted be so inserted-put . The Committee divided. Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hume-Minister of Trade and Customs) [10.25] - hope 1 that the honourable member will not press his amendment, because the Government are quite prepared to enter into any reasonable preferential agreement with the Government of Canada. I understand that within the past few days a cablegram has been published in the press indicating that the Dominion Government lis communicating with the Prime Minister with a view to ascertaining whether it is not possible to enter into some such arrangement. When that communication is received, the matter can be dealt with. If we can make any fair reciprocal arrangement with the Dominion Government, I can assure the honourable member that we shall embrace the opportunity to do so.
