Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hume-Minister of Trade and Customs) [10.41] - In view of the vote that has just been taken, and the decision arrived at, I move That after the words "Strippers, each Â£ 8 , " the words " and on and after 8th September, 1906, Â£ 6 , " be inserted. This will bring the duty more into line with that which the Committee has just decided shall be imposed on stripper-harvesters.

Speaker: Mr HUTCHISON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hindmarsh) [10.42] - The Government are placing their supporters in a very peculiar position. I said last night that I was entirely in favour of their proposals, but we now find the Government running away from them, although they have not been defeated. I do not feel inclined to depart from the views that I expressed last night, but the action of the Government may give rise to misapprehension as to the position occupied by some honourable members. It is questionable whether the duty on strippers ought to be reduced. I should like the Minister to inform the Committee what is the difference between the cost of making a stripper and that of' manufacturing a stripper-harvester? Some honourable members may assert that a higher duty than the present one means prohibition, but I do not think so. Even if that were so, it would be an inducement to me to vote for the duty. I shall not quarrel with the Government f f AYES. they think that they are making a fair proposal in view of the reduction of the duty upon stripper-harvesters. I merely wished to make mv position clear.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Boothby) [10.47]. - I understand that strippers are sold at J- from Â£ 4 5 to Â£ 5 5 , and if that be so, the proposedduty of Â£ 8 would correspond more closely than would Â£ 6 , with the duty imposed upon stripper-harvesters.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hume-Minister of Trade and Customs) [10.48] - When the duties were first decided upon, they were based upon a 25 per cent, ad valorem impost, and were fixed with due regard to the relative values of the machines. In view of the fact that the duty upon stripper harvesters Has been reduced by one-fourth, NOES. I am seeking to reduce the duty upon strippers in similar proportion, and thus Hutchison, J. preserve the harmony which characterized Tudor, F. G. the original proposals.  imported.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That isi my impression, because I know that strippers are one of the most common articles of manufacture by country implement makers. Amendment agreed to. Amendment (by Sir WILLIAM LYNE) proposed - That after the words " Metal parts of stripper harvesters and strippers, per lb., 2Â£d.," the words " and on and after 8th September, per lb., 2d.," be inserted.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: New England) [10.50] - I understand that the metal parts referred to can be obtained at from 12s. to 16s. per cwt., and, as 2d. per lb. would be equivalent to 18s. 8d. per cwt., it will be seen that the duty would be equivalent to over 100 per cent, ad valorem. It would be absurd to impose any such duty. It appears to me that although honourable members were elected under a pledge to preserve fiscal peace, they are intent upon introducing prohibition. If the present proposal were carried it would be in distinct violation of the pledge given to the electors. At the very outside, the duty should not exceed 25 per cent, ad valorem; therefore nothing beyond a duty of id. per lb. should be imposed. Local manufacturers find it to their advantage to import some of the parts instead of making them here, and if we impose too high a duty we shall penalize our manufacturers, and at the same time place unnecessary obstacles in the wav of owners of imported machines who may require duplicate parts. I wish to encourage the manufacturing industry, but not by imposing duties. My desire is to make everything free of duty. It seems to me surd to attempt to force our industries along to an extent that is not warranted by the requirements of the community. I feel very strongly disposed to move that the duty should be 25 per cent, ad valorem.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Corinella) [10.55] - If my memory serves me rightly, a request was made by some of the manufacturers for a duty of Â£ 2 5 upon stripper-harvesters and a duty of 2^d. per lb. upon the metal parts. The proposed duty upon the parts was regarded as corresponding with and proportionate to the Â£ 25 duty upon the completed machines. Therefore 2d. per lb. would not be the equivalent of the reduced duty of Â£12 per machine. I am informed that, roughly speaking, there is a ton of metal parts in a stripper-harvester, in a duty of 2d. per lb. upon such parts would represent an impost of Â£ 1 8 13s. 4d. - a n amount very largely in excess of the duty proposed to be levied on the completed machine. The Tariff Commission recommended that there should be an increased duty on only some of the parts, namely, malleable castings, and that the duty should be fixed at 20 per cent., and not 25 per cent. Consequently the Government proposal of 2d. per lb.' is largely in excess the proportion which it should bear to the duty upon the completed machine, and also largely in excess of the amount proposed by the Tariff Commission. In view of the reduction of.the duty upon stripper-harvesters to Â£1,2, the duty on the parts should be reduced to id. or i j d . per lb. If we impose too high a duty, it will operate to the detriment of the farmers, who will have to pay very much higher prices for duplicate parts of imported machines. So far as I can work it out, i d . is the proper proportion of duty according to the Tariff Commission's report. To my mind, it would be detrimental to our farmers to place a high duty on parts.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Part s are always sold at prices proportionately higher than those charged for complete machines.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Yes , and to put a high duty on them will increase that difference, and burden those who now have imported machines.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Moira) [n.3] - The duty on stripper-harvesters has been reduced by one-fourth.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Is not a duty of -2\&. per lb. on parts out of proportion when abcompared with the original duty of Â£ 1 6 on a stripper-hars'ester ?

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not think so, talking into consideration the amount of metal. The machines vary in weight froiir 23 to 26 cwt. The parts of the American machines are known as malleable castings.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The duty covers all metar parts.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Would it cover wheels ?

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Yes ; metal wheels.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: In my opinion, the importers deal very unfairly with customers who want duplicate parts. For three duplicate steering wheels they charge, according to their catalogue, Â£ 2 0 5s., while the Australian manufacwhich case turers charge only Â£ 1 4 .

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The proposed, duty would increase that trouble.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: In my opinion, it is relatively not so high as a fixed duty of Â£ 1 2 oh each machine.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: What is the weight of the ' three wheels to which the honourable member referred?

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable and of learned member may be able to get that information by examining the catalogue.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The makers' profits come largely from the sale of parts.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: For that reason we should be careful not to allow parts to be imported at duties relatively lower than are charged for machines. Otherwise, we may have parts imported and put together here.

Speaker: Mr FRAZER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Supposin g the weight cf a machine to be 24 cwt, a duty of 2d. per lb. on parts would be equivalent to Â£22 8s. on the completed machine.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I canr.ot say offhand how much of a harvester is wood and how much is metal; but I think that 2d. is a fair duty to impose on parts, having regard to the fact that the duty upcn the machines is Â£ 1 2 each.

Speaker: Mr BROWN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Canobolas) [n.9] - On e of the reasons why farmers buy imported machines is that it is easier to get satisfactory parts for them in the event of repairs being needed, or replacements becoming necessary! " The Australian manufacturers have not given sufficient attention to the manufacture of duplicate parts, whereas with the Americans it is a specialty. It is a common experience with farmers to have tremble with Australian duplicate parts, which very often do not fit. That has been my experience. Moreover, the American parts are more durable than the Australian parts. The Tariff Commissioners, speaking on this subject, sayMost of the parts of an imported stripperharvester consist of malleable castings, in the manipulation and use'of malleable castings that the secret of the success of American and duty ? Canadian competition in Australia is to be found. The Americans and Canadians used very little forged iron, every joint or boss, or anything that kind, is made out of malleable iron, means a great saving -(Q . 16158.) On the hand, the Australian implements are made offorged iron, or steel, which is more expensive. Malleable castings are not made in any tity in Australia, and such as are made sent are not so cheap as those imported. rageous one. America has practically a monopoly in the - duction of malleable castings, and can easily undersell local manufacturers. Australian facturers cannot produce the essential parts the machine as cheaply as their Canadian American rivals; such parts can only be out cheaply in the form of malleable castings. The honourable and learned member for Corinella is right in drawing attention this matter. If the duty were made high it would prejudice the users of magret" chines. I find that in 1905 the parts ported into New South Wales were valued at Â£ 1 1 , while those imported into land were valued at Â£398, and those imidea, ported into South Australia at Â£1,325 ; the interest of both farmers and manufacthese turers-until the local industry has proved its manufacture of parts-wil hest served by keeping down the duty on assistance parts. Instead cf reducing the proposed seen offers the duty by only Jd., I think that it should be "reduced by i j d .

Speaker: Mr MCCOLL
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Echuca) [n.15] - We ought to be very careful as to what action we take in this matter, because I am it is not the desire of any honourable ber that the farmers who have purchased American machines during the last year two should be penalized. Within the from abroad. period indicated there has been considerable competition between the various foreign implement makers, and that competition had the effect of reducing the price of harvester to the Australian farmer. I would not be fair to penalize him now requiring him to pay a heavy duty upon the duplicate parts which he may require for the machines which are already Those parts would be difficult to obtain locally. Many of them are patented, and could not be made here. They have to be manufactured by a peculiar process of annealing. They are first cast in the ordinary way, and then put into furnaces for some days, during which period they become very tough., I should like to know if the Minister cannot see his way to meet those who have already purchased Ameriand it is can machines, and allow those who may purchase them hereafter to pay the full

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: New England) of [n.18] - When Mr MCKay appeared bewhich fore the Tariff Commission he stated that other these malleable castings could be landed here at from 2^d. to 3d. per lb. The quanMinister's proposal to levy a duty of 2d. at preper lb. upon them is therefore an outI t is quite natural that promanufacturers should charge relatively more manufor the duplicate parts of these machines of than they do for the machines themselves. and Assuming that they are of the weight inturned dicated by Mr MCKay, their cost at 2|d. per lb. would work out at Â£ 3 8 . If we levy upon these duplicate parts the heavy to duty proposed by the' Minister we shall too merely be penalizing the farmers. I rethat there is no disposition on the part imof Victorian representatives to view this matter from a broad and liberal standQueenspoint. They are imbued with only one namely, that of enriching local manuand facturers. Personally I am of opinion that duplicate parts should be admitted imfree. The only State in the Commonl be wealth which is pleading for Government in these matters is Victoria. I may tell Committee that I have to manufacture these parts for about 16s. per cwt., so that the duty proposed by the Government is equivalent to an impost of quite 100 per cent. I appeal to the protectionists to be reasonable in sure this matter. Even the honourable member memfor Moira must recognise that the proposed duty would constitute a heavy tax upon or those who have already purchased machines

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Moira) [11.25] - I has estimate that the maximum weight of the the duplicate parts that would be required durt ing the life of an ordinary harvester would by be 5 cwt. Except in case of accident, the only parts which a farmer would need to renew would be the bearings, the spindles, in use. and the segment of the main driving wheel. The life of an ordinary harvester is about twelve years. I am estimating that during that period it harvests 250 acres each season, or a total of 3,000 acres. I venture to say that my estimate is a fair statement of the position. I feel confident that the weight of metal in the duplicate parts that would need to be renewed would not exceed 5 cwt., or, roughly speaking, 600 lbs. A duty of 2d. per lb. upon these parts would therefore mean Â£ 5 , which amount distributed over twelve years would be equivalent to 8s. 4d. per annum. The proposal of the Government, if adopted, will bring this duty into harmony with the duties that have already been agreed to. My contention is that the imposition of a protective duty causes a reduction in the price of the article protected.

Speaker: Mr HUTCHISON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: There would be' no sense in importing these duplicate parts.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Exactly . The point which I wish to emphasize is that there will be no increase in the cost of these parts if we adopt the proposal of the Government.

Speaker: Mr FRAZER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Kalgoorlie) [11.30] This is a proposal that requires to be carefully considered, and in respect of. which more information should be forthcoming from the' Minister. Whilst I am prepared to vote for a duty which will give the Australian manufacturer the local market-subjec t to certain conditions as to selling prices, and so forth- I do not propose to erect a tariff wall against the introduction of parts that may be required under circumstances that render it impossible to impose the conditions I have mentioned. We must be careful not to impose such a duty on parts as would nullify the provision we have made in regard to the complete machine. I have made a rough calculation as to what would be the effect of the Government proposal. Assuming, that the weight of the machine complete is about 24 cwt., a duty of 2d. per lb. on the whole of the weight would amount to about Â£ 2 2 8s.

Speaker: Mr HUTCHISON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: But the honourable member is wrong in his premises. It is not proposed to impose a duty in. respect of the total weight.

Speaker: Mr FRAZER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: A duty of 2d. per lb. would amount to Â£ 2 2 8s. on all the parts necessary to make up a complete machine. This successfully disposes of the objection that under this provision it would be possible for these parts to be imported and fitted up for sale as a machine, since the duty paid in respect of them would be double that imposed upon the completed article. If only three-fourths of the weight of the machine were subjected to this duty the total impost would be about Â£ 1 6 16s. per machine, so that even under that duty no one would think of importing the parts separately and assembling them here. My experience leads me to agree with the honourable member for Moira that the main bearings, spindles, segments, and, perhaps, one or two others, are the parts most likely to require renewal, and that we must be careful to impose such a duty as not to place at a disadvantage those who already own imported machines, and may require any of these duplicate parts. In the circumstances, therefore, I think that a duty of i j d . per lb. on parts-whic h would be equal to about Â£ 1 3 in respect of the complete machine-woul d afford effective protection. If the Minister will accept my proposal, he will deal fairly with the Australian manufacturer, and at the same time safeguard the interests of the consumers.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Wide Bay) [ n - 3 i ] There is a good deal of force in the remarks just made by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, but there is another aspect of this question that yet remains to be dealt with. I refer to the fact that stripper harvesters, on which we have imposed a duty of Â£ 1 2 , are not brought out here as complete machines. As a matter of fact, the parts are largely assembled here. That is a point that should not be overlooked. The proposal of the Government is to impose on duplicate parts a duty which will be almost double that on the complete machine. As some parts are in greater demand than others, it might pay those who supply them to import from time to time complete machines, and to sell them in separate pieces. Whilst I held office ss Minister of Trade and Customs it was urged that importers should be compelled to bring out their machines in a complete state, the idea being that the cost of transit would in that way be increased. Such a proposition would be scouted by any man who believes that no one should be subjected to unnecessarily costly shipping freights. The imposition of a high duty would undoubtedly be unjust to these who have alreadv ' purchased machines from oversea. Parts have to be replaced from time to time, and it would be unjust to penalize, the owner of one of these machines to the extent of even jQi per annum in respect of the duty on parts requiring to be renewed. I am sure the Committee does not desire that those who purchased machines under the Tariff prevailing prior to the introduction of these proposals should be prejudiced in any way or disadvantaged by a sudden increase of duty. The proposed duty is too high. I think that a duty of i j d . per lb. would be ample. I have a suggestion to make to overcome the difficulty in regard to those who have already purchased imported machines. My proposal is that for six or twelve months we should allow these parts to come in at the rate of i d . per lb., so that those requiring duplicates could obtain the necessary stock.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Does the honourable member know that the importers have frequently thrown an implement completely out of order owing to their inability to supply, perhaps, one component part.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is a serious charge to make. If importers carry on business in that way it is, to say the least, surprising that they obtain any sale for their machines. Even in that regard the local manufacturers have a great advantage over their foreign competitors. I trust that the Minister will, be able to see his way to permit of the almost free importation of metal parts of harvesters and strippers, so that those who require duplicate parts for imported machines may not be unduly penalized. I am sure that honourable members have no desire to inflict an injustice.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hume-Minister of Trade and Customs) [11.46] - I find that some difficulty was experienced in substituting a fixed duty for the ad valorem duty recommended by the Tariff Commission, and an approximate amount had to be adopted. The prices of the parts range from about 2d. per lb. to is. i d . per lb., and a fixed duty of 2^d. would correspond as nearly as possible with a duty of Â£ 1 6 per machine. I think that, if anything, 2id. per lb. is equivalent to something slightlv in excess of 25 per cent., because the departmental officers had to strike an average of the various prices. As a rule, only the smaller parts are imported. Having regard to all the circumstances. \ am willing to reduce the duty to if d . per lb. Amendment, by leave, withdrawn. Amendment (by Sir WILLIAM LYNE) proposed - That after the words "Metal parts of stripper harvesters and strippers, per lb., xÂ±A." the words " and on and after Sth September, per lb., if d . " be inserted.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Corangamite) [11.48] It has been suggested to me by the honourable member for Echuca that the proposed new duty should not become operative for six months, in order to enable those who possess machines to obtain duplicate parts at reasonable cost.

Speaker: Mr FRAZER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If that course were adopted a splendid opportunity would be afforded for speculative importations.

Speaker: Mr MCCAY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Corinella) [11.49] - I raised some questions with regard to the proposed duty on metal parts, and I have since obtained information, not only from the Minister, but from the Customs officers. According to my calculations the proposed duty of if d . per lb. works out very closely to the equivalent of the Â£ 1 2 duty on the stripper-harvesters, and I shall, therefore, support the amendment. Amendment agreed to. Amendment (by Sir WILLIAM LYNE) proposed - That after the words "Combined cornsheller and husker," the words "fertilizers and seed drills" be inserted.  why this addition is proposed?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hume-Minister of Trade and Customs) [11.52] - It has been represented to me that seed drills and fertilizers are very largely made here, and that there is no reason why all our requirements should not be supplied by local; manufacturers.

Speaker: Mr GB EDWARDS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: What are the present duties?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: 12 \ per cent.. These implements come within the same, category as the other articles with which they are bracketed. Amendment agreed to.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Parramai: i [ -53]-- moveIT 1 That after the words " ad valorem, 25 per cent." the words " and on and after 8th September, 1906, 15 per cent." be inserted. I think that we should adopt the old Victorian duty.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Victorian duty immediately preceding Federation was 15 pei cent., but prior to 1805 the duty was 20 per cent. The evidence given before the Tariff 'Commission shows that the troubles of the manufacturers commenced from the date that the duties upon implements were reduced to 15 per cent.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I think that we shall do well to adopt the old Victorian duties, under which the industry with which we are now dealing, and others, flourished. If the Victorian Parliament thought fit to reduce the duty from 20 per cent, to 15 per cent., further reason is afforded why we should adopt the latter rate. We have been told by the representatives of Victoria that all sorts of misfortunes have befallen the manufacturers of that State since the rates of duty prevailing under the old Victorian Tariff were abandoned and lower duties were substituted by the Commonwealth Parliament. They have represented that prosperity would be fully restored if the old Victorian duties were revived. Certainly, the Victorian manufacturers did well enough, and the implement makers sufficiently taxed the Victorian farmers under a 15 per cent, impost.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hume-Minister of Trade and Customs) [11.57] - In this case we are proposing to adopt the recommendation of the protectionist members of the Tariff Commission.

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: This is the first time that the Minister has done so.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The only reason why I did not accept the recommendation of the Commission with regard to harvesters and strippers was that I considered it preferable to fix a specific duty in order to avoid the difficulties, of valuation for the pay for it. purposes of an ad valorem duty.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Dalley) [11.59] - I shall support the amendment. I think that, as the Victorian Parliament,' possiblyled by the Prime Minister, adopted a rate of 15 per cent., and as the other States, particularly New South Wales, were not accustomed to these high duties, it is asking us to make too big a plunge to propose a duty of 25 per cent. that the Government will accept the compromise which has been offered.

Speaker: Mr MCWILLIAMS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Franklin) [12.2]. - Ha d not the amendment been moved, I should have asked the Committee to leave out all these items, with a view to leaving the duties upon them as they stand in the original Federal Tariff. The House of Representatives, after thoroughly threshing the matter out. agreed to a duty of 15 per cent, on the articles under review, which the Senate made 10 per cent., and 12^ per cent, was fixed upon as a compromise. The Victorian rate, which was the highest in Australia on agricultural implements, was only 15 per cent., and I ask honourable members, not to put a heavier duty on the farmers' tools of trade. The question which I hope the country will be asked to decide' within the next few weeks is whether the great primary industries of Australia exist for the sake of a few Melbourne manufacturers, or whether the Melbourne manufacturers exist for the sake of those who buy their machines. We are continually hearing from those who advocate the piling up of duties that the manufacturers say this and that; but surely the users of these implements deserve consideration. My experience has been that the farmers receive very little consideration at the hands of honourable members. A majority is always ready to vote for duties which will bleed the farmer to enrich the wealthy few in the cities. The members of the Labour Party talk of the necessity of distributing among the many the wealth which is now in the hands of a few, and yet they help the protectionists to compel the poor to contribute out of their poverty to the wealth of the few by swelling the bank balances of the Melbourne manufacturers. The honourable member for Moira on Wednesday night occupied nearly three hours in trying to make four points. One was that, because, in the early days, a number of persons received, grants of land for very small sums, the people who have purchased that land ought' to be made to

Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is not a right construction to place on what I said.

Speaker: Mr MCWILLIAMS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is the construction placed upon it by the Chairman of Committees. Another point made by the honourable member was that the higher the duties on articles of trade the cheaper will those articles be to the consumers. A third point was that, because the Victorian I trust farmers get certain railway concessions, the farmers of the Commonwealth must pay more for their tools of trade, in order to benefit certain Victorian manufacturers.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY

The Minister proposes to make him pay that amount in duty, in addition to the charges of importation. I wish to see Australian industries flourish; but they should not ten one upon the other. are necessaries to the tillers of the soil. It is absurd to try to encourage immigraduced tion, and to speak of appointing a High Commissioner at an enormous salary for tentionof that purpose, and at the same time to tax the farmers' tools of trade - Whe

Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Corangamite) [12.37] But that the honourable member for Parramatta forstalled me, I should have moved this amendment. I appeal to those who supported the Victorian Tariff of 1895the honourable member for Laanecoorie, the Attorney-General, and also, I think, the Prime Minister, who were at that time members of the Victorian Parliament, and who I believe supported most of the duties then submitted-to stand by this amendment.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Does the honourable member say that all whom he named voted on that occasion for a duty of 15 per cent.?

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No ; but I believe that most of them did. I am certain that the honourable member for Laanecoorie did.

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is so.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Referenc e has been made during this debate to the speech delivered in 1892 by the present Attorney General, in which he strongly deprecated prohibition, and spoke in favour of the farmer, and the reduction of duties relating to his tools of trade.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I spoke in favour of protection, but not of prohibition.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is all that I am urging, and I appeal to honourable members to support this amendment.

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Laanecoorie) [12.39] Many things have happened since the Victorian State Parliament dealt with the State Tariff eleven years ago. So far as the protective policy of the Commonwealth is concerned, I stand today in a position very different from that which I occupied in relation to the protective policy of Victoria. The incidence of protection has since been varied. I ' am glad to say that the policy of protection now embraces not only manufacturers as it did in the olden PAIRS. days, but has regard for the welfare of the employees as well as the consumers, and I am prepared therefore to support the recommendation of the Tariff Commission that an additional duty be imposed. C. C - Mr LONSDALE (New England) [12.41] - I .agree with the honourable member for Laanecoorie that there have been many changes since the consideration of the Victorian Tariff by the State Legislature in 1895. The Victorian manufacturers have now a much wider market than they then enjoyed, and the exports of Victorian-made agricultural implements into the other States are considerably in excess of the imports of the same class entering this State.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The Victorian manufacturers could export agricultural implements into New South Wales even in 1895.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member occasionally wakes up to say something that is not very sensible. The Victorian agricultural implement makers may have been able to send some machinery into the Riverina, which is nearer the Melbourne than the Sydney market.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: They did that eleven years ago.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I do not know whether I can get into the honourable member's dense head the fact that they sent implements to the Riverina, near the Victorian border.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: In those days even farmers in the electorate of New England used Victorian-made ploughs.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Perhaps they did. But the exports of Victorian-made agricultural implements into New South Wales are much larger now than they were prior to Federation. I do not object to this, for I am a free-trader, and would give every man the fullest freedom. The proposal of the Government is an outrageous one. Victoria has been working under the policy of protection for fourteen years, and it is the only State that is howling for more protection. The more she gets the more she likes it. If the whole of the agricultural implement business of the Commonwealth were captured by the local manufacturers they would not be able to afford employment to more than 600 men. It is now calmly proposed that the whole body of farmers shall be taxed in order to find employment for this number of artisans. Some consideration should be shown for our settlers, and this Parliament should not be looked upon as one which is specially concerned in protecting the interests of manufacturers.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Dalley) [12.47] - The honourable member for New England has en|tered a vigorous protest against the imposition of protective duties. I quite agree with him that Victoria is a perfect cormorant, as far as protection is concerned.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hear , hear; a greedy vulture.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That State has never been satisfied with the Tariff, and avails herself of every occasion to secure an increase of duties. Her manufacturers have apparently an insatiable appetite for protecregard tion.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Riverina) [12.48] The honourable member for New England, whose ignorance is equalled only by his arrogance

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Order ! The honourable member must withdraw those terms.

Speaker: Mr CHANTER
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: If I have committed a breach of parliamentary rule I shall withdraw the observation. I am not going to sit quietly by and allow the honourable correct. member to insult me. I have travelled through the New England district, and know that the farmers there are among the slowest in Australia. Many years ago, however, when they were free to choose whatever implements they liked, they elected to buy Victorian ploughs, because the manufacturers of that State produced implement exactly suited to their requireand ments, and which became recognised as the finest in the world. Moreover, most of the mining machinery in the honourable member's district was made at Ballarat. The honour against able member must concede to others the right to hold their own opinions as to what is best for the country, and honourable bers should not be described by ignorant simply because they happen to differ from him. The honourable member is not acquainted with even the political economy, and does not know what free-trade is. He never had the courage to vote for free-trade in New South Wales statement. when he. was under the leadership of late Sir Henry Parkes, or of the right orable member for East Sydney. He has truth. always preached, free-trade, but has voted protection when it has suited his constituday). ents. Now, however, that it is proposed to impose protective duties for the benefit of the people of the whole of Australia, the honourable member poses as a friend of the farmers. Free-traders of the type of the honourable member are the greatest enemies of the farmers.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: New England) [ -53]--The honourable member states that I2 the farmers in my electorate use Victorian ploughs, and that those implements are the best in. the world. It seems to me that my constituents are showing their common sense by obtaining the best implements available. I do not object to their using Victorian ploughs or any other kind of implements, but I object to their being limited in their choice. With to mining machinery, I need only remark that if the Victorian manufacturers can. compete with the rest of the world they should not need any protection. The honourable member made another statement which I should properly describe by using a very short good old British word. I have always voted in this House and elsewhere in accordance with my beliefs, and when the honourable member said that I had voted protection, he stated that which was not correct, and knew that it was not

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: New England) [2.17]. be in the interests of the masses. - I think that the honourable member for Maranoa is perfectly right in his contenimplements tion. In years past, the particular orable members to whom he referred, were satisfied with a duty of 15 per cent., cause the working man was not then deriving any advantage from it under the law. To-dav. however, the position is very him ? different. The proposed increase of duty is sought not in the interests of the workers, but in the interests of the manufacturers. The latter are compelled to pav higher wages than they did formerly, and to comcommunitv,ply with certain conditions, and as a sult the Victorian representatives in this Tariff. Committee wish to recoup them at the expense of the farmer. I am glad that the honourable member for Maranoa has seen through their little scheme. The proposed duty is championed for the purpose of increasing the price of imported ploughs, so that the local manufacturers will be able to demand a higher price. That higher price will be paid by the farmers of the Commonwealth. That is the idea underlying the imposition of the proposed duty. The representatives of Victoria are endeavouring to bolster up the local manufacturers with a view to " getting at " the general community. The articles enumerated in this schedule are the tools of trade of the farmer. I think that our manufacturers can make these implements just as successfully as they - are made elsewhere, but they are not satisfied to accept a similar rate of profit. This morning I stated that the annual value of agricultural implements imported into Australia was Â£329,000. I find, however, that I omitted to deduct from that sum the value of our exports which amounts to Â£48,000. It will be seen that the total annual value of the agricultural implements imported into the Commonwealth is only Â£280,000. If we'commanded the whole of the trade in this industry it would not afford very much additional employment. In years past, the wav in which the Attorney General fought for the poor farmer and miner was magnificent. One cannot read his speeches without realizing that his heart was touched by consideration for them.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS

text: How many of the honourable member's colleagues will follow

Let him clear his own doorstep before he makes suggestions of that character. The honourable member for Mernda laughs, but he will not laugh when he asks for the imposition of an additional half-penny per lb. on starch.

Speaker: Mr SALMON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member is indulging in personalities.

Speaker: Mr LONSDALE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The member is battling for the manufacturers. The duty upon the articles enumerated in this schedule should be reduced very considerably.  to draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that we have already determined that the price of stripper-harvesters shall be reduced within a certain period. There is, however, no such provision attaching to the articles specified in this schedule. Upon page 43 of the recommendations of the protectionist section of the Tariff Commission, I find that the only condition attached to harvesters readsPioviding that if the retail or selling price of any implement or machine made in Australia, similar to that upon which the additional duty is hereby imposed be raised above such prices ruling in Australia during 1905 .the Governor General may, in pursuance of a joint Address by the Senate and the House of Representatives, suspend the collection of such additional duty upon any machine or implement for such time as may be deemed advisable. I take it that if we increase the duty upon these articles without imposing a similar condition, we shall be fixing the price which rules to-dav for all time.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The provision says " not exceeding."  turers are not likely to reduce their prices if they are not liable to a penalty for their failure to do so. If they are to secure control of the home market, which means that they will obtain a much larger trade-w e should insert some stipulation regarding a reduction of price in the near future. What gain will the farmer derive - if the present price is to remain unaltered ?

text: Hume-Minister of Trade and Customs) [2.31] - I have given consideration to this question, and feel that it is difficult to say off-hand what the maximum selling price ought to be. In one case it has been suggested to me-and I have practically agreed-that there should be a reduction of 5 per cent, in the first year, and of 10 per cent, in the second. I shall embody in the Bill a clause which will be in accordance with the views expressed by the honourable member and those contained in the report of the Tariff Commission. When the Bill is submitted, honourable members will have an opportunitv to discuss what the maximum price should be, and what reduction should be insisted upon.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Cowper) [2.33] - I support the amendment that the duty be reduced to 15 per cent., on the ground that ploughs and harrows are manufactured all over Australia, and that the industry is not by any means confined to Melbourne. We have large manufacturing works in New South Wales, which, under free-trade, were able to compete successfully with the imported article.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: They do not make ploughs very successfully.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Blacksmiths all over New South Wales make ploughs that give results as satisfactory as those obtained from the Victorian ploughs. I rose chiefly, however, to reply to the remark made by'the honourable member for Bland that protection would not increase the price of these articles.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I said that it need not, and that under this proposal it should not, because we have fixed a maximum iselling price for harvesters, and can do the same in regard to ploughs.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: My point is that the effect of this duty will be to increase the cost of imported ploughs. But for these duties, the farmer would obtain his tools of trade cheaper.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Not at all. If he locally-made implements, he will probably secure them at a lower price than before.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND

Speaker: Mr ISAACS

text: Why should not the farmer buy an Australian plough ?

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I am proud to say that they can. Prior to the imposition of heavy protective duties, implement makers in New South Wales were able to compete successfully in, and in many cases to drive the foreign competitor out of, the local market. I liave only to point out, in conclusion, that if we impose a duty of 20 per cent, it will mean that every pound which the farmer spends in buying these machines will be worth only 16s. to him.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Corangamite [2.37] Shortly before the luncheon adjournment I referred to some votes on the Tariff given in the Victorian Parliament in 1895, and said that the Attorney-General was one of those who supported the reduction of a certain duty. On turning to Hansard, I find that I was mistaken-that the honourable and learned gentleman on that occasion voted not for a proposed reduction, but for the maintenance of a high duty.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: What was the rate?

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It was proposed that a prohibitive Tariff. duty of 30 per cent, should be reduced to 15 per cent., and the honourable and learned member voted for the higher duty.

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: So did I .

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable and learned member for Bourke, the honourable and I say and learned member for Northern Melto frustrate bourne, and the honourable member for Gippsof land, also voted against the reduction, whilst the honourable member for Melbourne vation. was paired with the " Noes." On the other hand, the Prime Minister, the honourable told member for Moira, the honourable member told for Echuca. and the honourable member for they Laanecoorie, all voted for the reduction of the duty to 15 per cent, When I referred to this matter this morning, the honourable buys member for Mernda interjected that he and other honourable members voted for a duty of 15 per cent, because they could not secure a higher one. It now transpires that the boot was on the other foot-that they voted for the reduction of the duty. On that occasion the Attorney-General was consistent; he showed that he was advancing from protection to prohibition.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No .

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I make that statement advisedly, for during the Tariff debate of 1892 the honourable and learned gentleman strongly deprecated prohibition.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: What was the rate of duty to which I objected in 1892 ?

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable and learned gentleman objected to a rate which he said was bordering on prohibition, he was deprecating the imposition of a duty in respect of the tools of trade of farmers and miners which he said would amount to prohibition.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Hear , hear.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable and learned gentleman says that he would do the same thing today.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: What was the higher rate which the Attorney-General was opposing?

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: About 45 per cent.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: And when I voted for a duty of 30 per cent., I , as a member of the Government of the day, was carrying out the principles that I enunciated in 1892 by reducing the former duties.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: On the recommendation of a Tariff .Commission. I wish to be perfectly fair, and I may say at once that I endorse what the Attorney-General said on the occasion in question.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It related to a specific

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I have already said that it did. Speaking in the Legislative Assembly on 6th October, 1962, the Attorney General said: that it is .the duty of the Government of the committee to see that nothing is done the desire of the country districts, the country generally, to open out the means of production which are alone to prove our salWe were told the other evening by the Minister of Lands that in the Cabinet there is a strong farmers' interest. I recognise it. He us that the farmers were well protected. He us that they had nothing to lose, and that were well provided for in comparison with the other sections of the community. Unfortunately for myself, I have not the good fortune of agreeing with the honourable gentleman. We are told that the farmer has his reaper and his binder free. So he has. Is his plough free? Is his harrow free? Is his chaff-cutter free? Is the very twine with which duce free? Certainly not. This shows that the farmer has much to gain, and that there is much that he ought to gain, before he is placed on a level with his more fortunate brother in the town. I endorse this statement, and refer to it as something that is pertinent to the question before the Chair. I should like at this stage to read what was said by Mr now Senator-Best , a member of the Victorian Government, who was in charge of the Tariff Revision Bill in the State Legislative Assembly. At page. 1088 of the Victorian Hansard, vol. 77, session 1895-6. Mr Mclntyre is reported to have interjected, in the course of a speech by that gentleman : " Would you accept the amendment, then?"' To this he replied:The Government could, not accept the amendment, for the reason that in some instances it would have the - effect of making a reduction from 30 to 15 per cent. So far as agricultural implements were concerned, the Government simply accepted the recommendation of the Tariff Board, and it would appear that it was not against the wish of some of the agricultural implement makers, at all events, that the proposal to reduce the duty from 20 to 15 per was made. That was the duty on agricultural implements.

Speaker: Mr MCWILLIAMS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: How did the Attorney-General vote on that proposal?

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: He voted with the Government for the maintenance of the higher duty.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member is absolutely wrong. I was a member of the Government of the day, and we brought in a Tariff reducing the existing one.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is so. mentioned that fact, and have shown that when an amendment was moved to still further reduce the duty on agricultural implements, the honourable and learned gentleman voted for the maintenance of the higher rate.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: For the maintenance of the rate proposed by the Government of which I was a member.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Whic h was the higher rate.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: It was lower than that prevailing under the then existing Tariff.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The honourable member for Moira voted for the amendment to reduce the duty to 15 per cent. Tariff. 4215

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I voted then, as I am voting now, for what I believed to be effihe ties up his pro- cient duties.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The same considerations that then influenced the Prime Minister, the honourable member for Laancoorie, and the honourable member for Echuca, should weigh with them now. The farmers have the same needs and necessities today as they had then. I am not advocating a reduction of the existing duty. Ploughs are now subject to a protective duty of izÂ£ per "cent., and I think that a 15 per cent, duty would afford fair protection, and would be as much as the farmer should be asked to pay. In fairness to the agriculturists, the ploughs to which I am referring, which are different from those manufactured in Victoria, should be admitted at the existing rate of duty. I admit that in the heavy classes of ploughs, the Victorian implements are among the best in the world, but the ploughs to which I have been referring are of a lighter class, suitable for woriking with one horse and for use in orchards and in light volcanic soils. Most of these ploughs have been cent, imported in the past, and we should give the farmer the advantage of a lower rate of duty. I would also suggest that plough mould-boards 'should be admitted free of duty. I am given to understand that imported mould-boards are almost entirely used by our implement manufacturers.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I think the honourable member must have misunderstood the representations made to him.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The information was given to me by a man who knows as much about farming as does the honourable member for Moira. I hope that before the I have proposed Bill leaves the Senate, inquiries will be made as to whether it would not be advisable tc? place mould-boards' on the free list.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Indi-^Attorney-General) [2.48] - I should like to say two or three words with reference to the remarks of the honourable member for Maranoa., who touched upon a question that goes to the root of all matters connected with protection. We have a very great Commonwealth-on e of great splendour and great promise. But, with all its magnificence, I shall not think much of it if it is not going to make happier and tetter the lot of the people in Australia who have to labour - My view of protection is that it is part of a great scheme for the amelioration of the lot of those, who have to labour- I draw no distinction between labourers, whether they use the plough, the pick, or the pen. I think that the honourable member for Maranoa was right when he said that we have to look" to the welfare of the workers who are engaged in these industries. I have never been an advocate of protection by means of Tariff duties merely to make fortunes for manufacturers, and I should like to inform the honourable member that the same Parliament that passed the Victorian Tariff in 1895 passed the Factories and Shops Act, which made provision for Wages Boardsthe first Act of its kind in Australia. In this House at the present time there are a number of honourable members, including the Prime Minister, the 'honourable member for Laanecoorie, the honourable and learned member for Northern Melbourne, the honourable member for Bourke, the honourable member for Moira, the honourable member for Gippsland, and others, who sat in that Parliament and gave protection to the manufacturers, not merely for the sake of the employers, but for the general welfare of the consumers and the workers. The same honourable members also helped to place upon the statute-book the Factories and Shops Act, which was a humane measure, and which was passed in spite of the resistance of the free-traders. It is the protectionists and not the free-traders, except connected withi the Labour Party, who have done so much for the workers of Australia.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The free-traders have done as much for the workers in New South Wales.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: That is because the Labour Party pressed them.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: No , the free-traders did it without any pressing.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: During the political history of Victoria the free-traders as such, have done very little indeed to soften the lot of the worker, and give him better conditions. I say that that is a fair answer to make to the honourable member for "Maranoa. I think that the Prime Minister can fairlv claim the credit of having originated the Factories and Shops Act. That measure was gradually developed, and eventually he was able, alonir with others, including myself, to put it upon the statute-book. We feel very strongly, and I think we can share the feelings of the honourable member for Maranoa, and those of the same political mould of thought as himself, that sweating is an abhorrent thing. We desire not only to prevent the Australian worker from being sweated by the man standing alongside him, but also to prevent him from being sweated by men working abroad. There is no reason why, whilst preventing sweating upon our own soil, we should at the same time allow the products of sweated labour to come into the Commonwealth, and compete with goods produced here. Therefore, I cannot understand how free-trade and labour legislation can go hand in hand. Labour legislation for the improvement of the lot of the workers forms one of the great parts of the scheme of protection, and I believe that our friends of the Labour Party will soon realise that they cannot provide means for paying good honest wages to the workers unless they protect the manufacturers from the. sweated labour of foreign countries.  afraid of. It is the products of highly paid labour that we fear. , Mr ISAACS - No , not on that ground. This is not the time to enter into details

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The " Attorney-General is attempting to make political capital, and is making a great show in front of the window.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: The goods in the window those are honest goods, and I do not care who sees them. I merely rose to answer a fair question put by the honourable member for Maranoa, and I think that I have replied fairly. With regard to the observations of the honourable member for Corangamite, the remarks I made upon the occasion mentioned I hold to now, and, if the same Tariff were before me, I should make the same statements. They have been quoted as if they were used in reference to protection, and not to that particular Tariff. But any one who honestly desires to find out what I meant may ascertain that I stated in the speech that the question of protection was not on the tapis. The matter under discussion was prohibition.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I hope the honourable member does not accuse me of having made unfair use of his observations. - Mr ISAACS - No , but the honourable member knows that they have been unfairly used. I stated that I was opposed to monopoly, caused either by unduly high duties amounting to prohibition, or monopoly due to the absence of a Tariff. My idea of protection is that we should impose reasonable duties as will permit fair honest wages to be paid in the regular consistent development of our native relabour backing. sources, and enable us to become a highly prosperous, civilized nation, self-sufficient and able to occupy a high place among the nations of the world.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Dalley) [2.57] - The Atciate his free-trade views with strong radi torney-General has indulged in a good of theatrical display and posturing, and has made a number of statements derogatory to the Free-trade Party. He stated in effect that the enactment of humane legislation was the special function' of protectionists only, and that the free-traders had not accomplished any good work in that direction, and therefore could not counted as upon the side of the workers. By his remarks he has libelled the honorcause able, and learned member for West Svdney. the honourable member for Canobolas, the honourable member for Maranoa, all staunch free-traders.

Speaker: Mr ISAACS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: I especially excepted the free-trade members of the Labour Partv.

Speaker: Mr WILKS
Title: AGRICULTURAL MACHINERY AND
text: Would the Attorneyof General have excepted those honourable members three years ago when they were sitting behind the right honourable member for East Sydney, who, as the leader of the Free-trade Party in Australia, has instrumental in passing humane legislation of a far more important character than the Victorian Shops and Factories Act.
